12.title: 2.1d. Form and Use the Past Tense of Frequently Occurring Irregular Verbs.

8.title: 1.2c. Use Commas in Dates and to Separate Single Words in a Series

42.title: 8.1b. Form and use verbs in the active and passive voice.

2.title: 1.1c. Use Singular and Plural Nouns with Matching Verbs in Basic Sentences.

43.title: 8.1d. Recognize and correct inappropriate shifts in verb voice and mood.

25.title: 6.1c Recognize and correct inappropriate shifts in pronoun number and person.

40.title: 7.1c. Place Phrases and Clauses Within a Sentence, Recognizing and Correcting Misplaced and Dangling Modifiers.

41.title: 7.2a. Use a Comma to Separate Coordinate Adjectives.

1.title: 1.1b. Use Common, Proper, and Possessive Nouns.

36.title: 5.2a. Use punctuation to separate items in a series.

33.title: 3.2c. Use commas and quotation marks in dialogue.

3.title: 1.1e. Use Verbs to Convey a Sense of Past, Present, and Future.

15.title: 2.2c. Use an Apostrophe to Form Contractions.

30.title: 3.1g. Form and use comparative and superlative adjectives and adverbs.

56.title: 2.1d Irregular Past Tense Verbs with Images

7.title: 1.2a. Capitalize Dates and Names of People.

14.title: 2.2a. Capitalize Holidays, Product Names, and Geographic Names.

38.title: 5.2b. Use a comma to separate an introductory element from the rest of the sentence.

23.title: 6.1a. Ensure that pronouns are in the proper case.

17.title: 4.1b. Form and use the progressive verb tenses.

37.title: 5.2c. Use a comma for yes and no, tag questions, and addressing people.

18.title: 4.1c. Use modal auxiliaries to convey various conditions.

44.title: 8.2b. Use an ellipsis to indicate an omission.

16.title: 4.1a. Use relative pronouns and relative adverbs.

27.title: 6.2a Use punctuation (commas, parentheses, dashes) to set off nonrestrictive/parenthetical elements.

classifications.47: Irregular Verbs in the Past Tense

314.description:
Correct: Let's go to the living room, where we will serve drinks. Incorrect: Let's go to the living room, when we will serve drinks.
Where is used to talk about something happening (serve drinks) in, on, or at a certain place (living room).
314.title: Where

503.title: Use Commas and Quotation Marks in Dialogue
503.description: Correct: A wise man one said, ""Doubt everything, find your own light."" Incorrect: A wise man once said ""Doubt everything, find your own light. We use a pair of quotation marks to show that someone is speaking. Whenever we use quotation marks, we always put a comma before the beginning of the quote (said,).

370.title: On (Place)
370.description:
Correct: My grandparents keep a picture of me on their mantle. Incorrect: My grandparents keep a picture of me at their mantle.
We use on for anything on a surface, like walls and tables.

182.description: Correct: My favorite team has lost only once this season. Incorrect: My favorite team has losed only once this season. The past participle for ""lose"" is lost.
182.title: Lost

164.description: Correct: A wise man one said, ""Doubt everything, find your own light."" Incorrect: A wise man once said ""Doubt everything, find your own light. We use a pair of quotation marks to show that someone is speaking. Whenever we use quotation marks, we always put a comma before the beginning of the quote (said,).
164.title: Use Commas and Quotation Marks in Dialogue

170.description: With Both: Both Tom and Michelle like swimming. Without Both: Tom likes swimming. Michelle also likes swimming. Both can be used with and to describe two things at the same time (Both Tom and Michelle). We place both before the first thing, then use and for the second thing.
170.title: Both ... And

221.title: Vocabulary: Cannot
221.description:
The sign said, ""You cannot pass here.""
When we write out ""can not"" we either can use the contraction form ""can't"" or we write cannot.
Can not is just a misspelled version of ""cannot,"" and is always incorrect.

271.title: Than vs. Then
271.description:
Than: I am older than my brother. Then: The sky was pink, and then it became dark.
We use than to compare two or more things. We use then to say ""at that time.""

440.description:
Separate: I will not sign anything until I've read the contract. Contraction: I won't sign anything until I've read the contract.
To make ""will"" and ""not"" a contraction, we write won't.
440.title: Won't

21.title: And
21.description:
Not Connected: I like spaghetti. I like hamburgers. Connected: I like spaghetti and I like hamburgers.
And connects two sentences into one longer sentence. In the example, we use and to show that the subject ( I ) likes both spaghetti and hamburgers.

453.description: Correct: My address is 79 Brookfield Lane, Springfield, Massachusetts 01234. Incorrect: My address is 79 brookfield lane Springfield, Massachusetts, 01234. When we write out our addresses, we always put commas after the name of the street (Brookfield Lane,) and after the name of the city (Springfield). Remember to capitalize both the street and state names, because they are proper nouns.
453.title: Practice: Use Commas in Addresses

318.title: Present Progressive
318.description:
Simple Present: Jesse thinks about seagulls. Present Progressive: Jesse is thinking about seagulls right now.
Present progressive tense describes an ongoing action that is happening right now (Jesse is thinking right now). This tense is made by putting words like ""am"", ""is"", and ""are"" before the verb, and adding ""ing"" to the end of the verb (is thinking).

166.description: Many Boys: Do not touch the boys' gear. One Boy: Do not touch the boy's gear. When multiple people or things own something we place an apostrophe after the ""s"" (boys'). When just one person or thing owns something we put the apostrophe before the ""s"".
166.title: Plural Possessive

514.title: Capitalization: Names
514.description:
Correct: Sarah's birthday is coming soon. Incorrect: sarah's birthday is coming soon.
We capitalize names of people (Sarah, Abraham Lincoln).

452.description: Correct: My address is 79 Brookfield Lane, Springfield, Massachusetts 01234. Incorrect: My address is 79 brookfield lane Springfield, Massachusetts, 01234. When we write out our addresses, we always put commas after the name of the street (Brookfield Lane,) and after the name of the city (Springfield). Remember to capitalize both the street and state names, because they are proper nouns.
452.title: Use Commas in Addresses

285.description:
That: The new classrooms that had their walls painted look great. Which: The new classrooms, which had their walls painted, look great.
We use which to give more details about something (new classrooms), but the details don't change the meaning of the sentence. In the first example, using ""that"" means only the painted classrooms look great. In the second example, using which means that the new classrooms look great, and they also happen to be painted. We usually place commas before which.
285.title: Which

280.description:
To: I sent an email to you. Too: Brett sent you an email too. Two: Pat sent you not one, but two emails.
To is used mostly to show where something is moving Too can either mean ""also"" or ""excessive."" Two is the number after ""one"".
280.title: To, Too, & Two

198.title: Meant, Mint
198.description:
The verb mean (to communicate, indicate, signify) has an irregular past tense form: meant. From this same root we get the noun meaning.
The noun mint refers to various aromatic plants whose highly flavored leaves are used in cooking (e.g. peppermint, spearmint). The same word also refer to a place where money is coined.

349.description:
Correct: After three years of practice, I became a skillful archer. Incorrect: After three years of practice, I becomed a skillful archer.
The past tense of ""become"" is became.
349.title: Became

299.title: When
299.description:
Correct: My favorite time of year is autumn, when all the leaves change color. Incorrect: My favorite time of year is autumn, where all the leaves change color.
When is used to to talk about something happening (leaves change color) in on, or at a certain time (autumn).

236.title: Multiple Sentences in a Quotation
236.description: Correct: ""I heard that walnuts are good for removing scratches on furniture. It could be an old wive's tale, however."" Incorrect: I heard that walnuts are good for removing scratches on furniture."" ""It could be an old wive's tale, however."" Not every sentence in a quotation needs quotation marks. Whenever something is said or stated, we write quotation marks at the very beginning and very end.

216.title: Vocabulary: Passed vs Past
216.description: The time to kick a field goal had already passed. ""Don't worry about the fight we had, its all in the past,"" I said to my brother. Passed is the past tense form of the verb to pass. Past has several meanings, but usually refers to an event that took place prior to the present.

89.description:
Adjective: I think this task is pretty simple. Adverb: You simply put the ball in the net.
Adjectives ending in ""le"" (simple), become adverbs by changing the ""le"" to ""ly""(simply).
89.title: Adjectives to Adverbs: Ending in ""le""

309.description:
Correct: My friend Steve, whose job is fun, loves going to work. Incorrect: My friend Steve, who job is fun, loves going to work.
We use whose to give more details about something the subject (Steve) owns (job).
309.title: Whose

253.description:
Correct: A doctor has an important job because she saves lives. Correct: A doctor has an important job because he saves lives. Incorrect: A doctor has an important job because they save lives.
Pronouns need to stay the same in gender (she, he) and number (they, them). This means that if the subject is singular (doctor), then any pronouns referring to it will will usually be singular as well (he, she).
253.title: Pronoun Shift: Singular

68.title: Yourselves
68.description:
Reflexive: I see that you all really applied yourselves for this assignment. Non-Reflexive: I see that you worked really hard for this assignment.
When we address multiple people (you all) doing something to themselves, we use a reflexive pronoun (yourselves).

378.description:
Indefinite Article: There is lots of pizza. I ate a slice. Definite Article: There was a loaded slice of bacon pizza. I ate the slice.
You use a definite article (the) to specify something (the slice of bacon pizza). You use an indefinite article (a, an) when you have not specified something (a slice).
378.title: The

307.title: Who
307.description:
Correct: Have you met the girl who started in grade 7 last week? Incorrect: Have you met the girl that started in grade 7 last week?
We use who to give more details about a person (the girl). Who is used for someone (the girl) who does an action (started in grade 7) instead of receiving an action.

248.description:
Correct: Todd has become a great student since he started studying more.
Incorrect: Todd has became a great student since he started studying more.
The past participle of ""go"" is gone.
248.title: Became

431.description:
Adjective: My car is really slow. Adverb: I drive slowly when it is raining.
Adverbs are used to describe verbs, adjectives, or other adverbs. They usually describe how an action is being done (drive slowly).
431.title: Adverbs

398.description:
Correct: Can you juggle the ball with both feet? Incorrect: Can you juggle the ball with both foots?
The word ""foot"" has an irregular plural form. To make it plural, we change the double ""o"" (foot) into a double ""e"" (feet).
398.title: Practice: Feet, Teeth

177.title: Yes & No
177.description: Correct: Yes, my husband is a lawyer. Incorrect: Yes my husband is a lawyer. Correct: No, I don't want to go. Incorrect: No I don't want to go. When we begin a sentence with yes or no, we always put a comma afterwards.

52.title: Ends with ""o""
52.description:
Correct: Do you know how many potatoes can fit in this sack? Incorrect: Do you know how many potatos can fit in this sack?
Nouns that end in ""o"" (potato) have an irregular plural form. To make them plural, we add an ""es"" to the end of the word (potatoes).

140.description:
Correct: Our project is more difficult than theirs. Incorrect: Our project is more difficult than they. Also Incorrect: Our project is more difficult than them.
Possessive pronouns (theirs) are words like ""mine"", ""yours"", ""his"", ""hers"", ""its"", ""ours"", and ""theirs"". They refer to something the subject owns (project).
140.title: Possessive Pronouns

384.title: Practice: Change into Proper Passive or Active Sentences

116.description:
Simple Past: James cleaned the mess he made when his mom walked in the room. Past Progressive: James was cleaning the mess he made when his mom walked in the room.
Past progressive tense describes something which was happening (was cleaning) when something else occurred (mom walked in). This tense is made by putting words like “was” or “were” before the verb and adding “ing” at the end of the verb (was cleaning).
116.title: Past Progressive

388.title: Practice: Change Sentences from Passive to Active

422.title: Practice: Future Tense
422.description:
Future: I will walk to school. Present: I walk to school.
We use the future tense to describe things that we think will happen. To make the future tense ( will walk ), we add the helping verb ""will"" before the verb ( walk ).

447.description:
Separate: I am responsible for managing the team. Contraction: I'm responsible for managing the team.
The contraction for """"I am"""" is made by writing I'm.
""
447.title: You're

403.title: Mouse vs. Mice
403.description:
Correct: I think there are some mice living in the walls. Incorrect: I think there are some mouses living in the walls.
The word ""mouse"" has an irregular plural form. To make it plural, we change the ""ouse"" (mouse) to ""ice"" (mice).

126.title: To, Too, & Two
126.description:
To: I sent an email to you. Too: Brett sent you an email too. Two: Pat sent you not one, but two emails.
To is used mostly to show where something is moving Too can either mean ""also"" or ""excessive"". Two is the number after ""one"".

277.description:
There: There is a park by the lake. They're: They're going to the park. Their: They left their frisbee at the park.
There is used for locations.
They're is the same as ""they are"".
Their is used when something (they) owns something else (frisbee).
277.title: There, They're, & Their

348.title: Made
348.description:
Correct: I made a vase out of clay. Incorrect: I maked a vase out of clay.
The past tense of ""make"" is made.

39.title: On (Time)
39.description:
Correct: I will meet with my counselor on Monday. Incorrect: I will meet with my counselor in Monday.
We use on for days of the week and certain dates, like Monday or October 30th.

328.description: ""Correct: Who here is the best at playing chess? Incorrect: Who here is the goodest at playing chess? The comparative adjective for """"good"""" is better. The superlative adjective for """"good"""" is best.""
328.title: Better & Best

451.title: Practice: Contractions
451.description:
Separate: I do not go to school on Saturday. Contraction: I don't go to school on Saturday.
To make ""do"" and ""not"" a contraction, we write don't.

363.title: At (Time)
363.description:
Is: John is behind the curtain. Are: The men are next to the bar. Am: I am under a bridge.
A nominal prepositional phrase is used to say where something is. Nominal prepositional phrases (behind the curtain, next to the bar, under a bridge) are placed after the verb to be (is, are, am).

43.description:
Correct: Sarah's birthday is coming soon. Incorrect: sarah's birthday is coming soon.
We capitalize names of people (Sarah, Abraham Lincoln).
43.title: Capitalization: Names

102.title: It's
102.description:
Separate: It is really great you decided to come. Contraction: It's really great you decided to come.
To make a contraction with ""it"" and ""is"", we write it's.

154.description:
Correct: 1,500,000 Incorrect: 1, 500, 000
We do not put a space before or after a comma when we are writing numbers.
154.title: Using Commas with Numbers

97.title: Won't
97.description:
Separate: I will not sign anything until I've read the contract. Contraction: I won't sign anything until I've read the contract.
To make ""will"" and ""not"" a contraction, we write won't.

464.description: With Still: I don't like roller coasters. Still, I think theme parks are fun. Without Still: I don't like roller coasters. I think theme parks are fun. We use still at the beginning of a sentence to say something is true despite what was said earlier. We place a comma after still (Still, I think theme parks are fun).
464.title: Still

396.description:
Correct: The group of women won the tug of war. Incorrect: The group of woman won the tug of war.
The word ""woman"" has an irregular plural form. To make it plural, we change the ""a"" (woman) to an ""e"" (women).
396.title: Man/Men, Woman/Women-2

437.description:
Adjective: You are brave enough to face your fears. Adverb: Rita bravely faced her fears.
Adjectives ending in ""e"" (brave), become adverbs by simply adding ""ly"" to the end of the word (bravely).
437.title: Adjectives to Adverbs: Ending in ""e""

162.description: Correct: My favorite book is called A Return to the Beginnings of Time and Space. Incorrect: My favorite book is called A return to the beginnings of time and space. When we write out titles, we always capitalize the first word in the title along with proper nouns and longer words. Smaller words like articles (the), conjunctions (but), and prepositions (to) remain in the lower case.
162.title: Capitalize Appropriate Words in Titles

366.title: On (Time)
366.description:
Correct: I will meet with my counselor on Monday. Incorrect: I will meet with my counselor in Monday.
We use on for days of the week and certain dates, like Monday or October 30th.

462.description: With However: My friend said the ride was safe. However, I didn't believe him. Without However: My friend said the ride was safe. I did not believe him. We use however at the beginning of a sentence to say ""nevertheless"" or ""but."" We place a comma after however (However, I did not believe him).
462.title: However

50.title: Ends with ""fe""
50.description:
Correct: Some people say cats have nine lives. Incorrect: Some people say cats have nine lifes.
Nouns that end in ""fe"" (life) have an irregular plural form. To make them plural, we change the ""fe"" (life) to ""ves"" (lives).

62.title: Myself
62.description:
Reflexive: I hit myself with a ball playing soccer yesterday. Non-Reflexive: I was hit with a ball while playing soccer yesterday.
If a subject (I) does something to itself, we use a reflexive pronoun (myself). In the second example, the subject (I) does not do something to itself, so we do not use a reflexive pronoun.

302.description:
Correct: My friend Steve, whose job is fun, loves going to work. Incorrect: My friend Steve, who job is fun, loves going to work.
We use whose to give more details about something the subject (Steve) owns (job).
302.title: Whose

48.title: Collective Nouns
48.description:
Correct: There is a huge crowd of people at the front gate. Incorrect: There is a huge crowds of people at the front gate.
Collective nouns are words like group, bunch, gallon, bouquet, etc. They usually are singular and describe a group of things (group of people).
If there are multiple groups of things, you pluralize the collective noun (two armies, two herds, etc). For example, if you are trying to say that there are two groups of soldiers, you say there are two armies, not two army.

410.description:
Examples: man, woman, city, country, baseball team.
Common nouns are ordinary words for people, places, and things, such as man, or country. Common nouns are not capitalized.
410.title: Practice: Common and Proper Nouns

273.description:
Than: I am older than my brother. Then: The sky was pink, and then it became dark.
We use than to compare two or more things. We use then to say ""at that time.""
273.title: Practice: Than vs. Then

358.title: Himself
358.description:
Reflexive: Steven sees himself becoming team captain one day. Non-Reflexive: I see Steven becoming team captain one day.
If a male subject (Steven) does something to himself, we use a reflexive pronoun (himself). In the second example, the subject (I) is seeing someone else, so we do not use a reflexive pronoun.

256.description:
Exactly two options: You can have either soup or salad._
Two or more options: You can have soup or salad.
Whenever either is placed before or, we are presented with exactly two options (soup or salad). If the two options share a verb, either is written after the verb (have either soup or salad). If the two options have different verbs, either is written before the first verb (You can either run or lift weights).
If there are two or more options, we do not use either, but still use or.
256.title: Either ... Or

322.description: Correct: James is taller than Steve. Incorrect: Jame is more tall than Steve. Comparative adjectives tell us how one thing (James) is ""more"" or ""less"" than another thing (Steve). Regular comparative adjectives are formed by adding ""er"" to the end of a word (**taller**).
322.title: Comparative Adjectives

394.description:
Correct: Are you mice, or are you men? Incorrect: Are you mice, or are you mans?
The word ""man"" has an irregular plural form. To make it plural, we change the ""a"" (man) to an ""e"" (men).
394.title: Man vs. Men

405.description:
Correct: I saw a bunch of geese flying in the sky. Incorrect: I saw a bunch of gooses flying in the sky.
The word ""goose"" has an irregular plural form. To make it plural, we change the ""oose"" (mouse) to ""eece"" (goose).
405.title: Mouse/Mice, Geese/Goose, Deer/Deer-2

28.description:
Incorrect: I saw a owl last night. Correct: I saw an owl last night.
A is used before nouns that start with a consonant sound (everything but a, e, i, o, u). An is used before nouns that start with a vowel sound.
28.title: An

55.title: Foot vs. Feet
55.description:
Correct: Can you juggle the ball with both feet? Incorrect: Can you juggle the ball with both foots?
The word ""foot"" has an irregular plural form. To make it plural, we change the double ""o"" (foot) into a double ""e"" (feet).

51.description:
Correct: Two halves always make a whole. Incorrect: Two halfs always make a whole.
Nouns that end in ""f"" (half) have an irregular plural form. To make them plural, we change the ""f"" (half) to ""ves"" (halves).
51.title: Ends with ""f""

483.title: Subjective Pronouns
483.description:
Correct: I will conduct the meeting. Incorrect: Me will conduct the meeting. Also Incorrect: Mine will conduct the meeting.
Subject pronouns (I) are words like ""I,"" ""you,"" ""he,"" ""she,"" ""it,"" ""we,"" ""you,"" and ""they."" They are usually near the front of the sentence and go before the verb.

315.description:
Correct: Let's go to the living room, where we will serve drinks. Incorrect: Let's go to the living room, when we will serve drinks.
Where is used to talk about something happening (serve drinks) in, on, or at a certain place (living room).
315.title: Practice: Where, Why, When

99.description:
Separate: I have not contacted Mrs. Robinson. Contraction: I haven't contacted Mrs. Robinson.
To make ""have"" and ""not"" a contraction, we write haven't.
99.title: Haven't

482.title: Practice: Intensive Pronouns vs. Reflexive Pronouns
482.description:
Intensive: I organized the meeting myself. Reflexive: I organized myself before going to the meeting.
Intensive Pronouns (myself) use the same words as reflexive pronouns (myself). However, when using intensive pronouns, the subject (I) emphasizes that it does something (organized the meeting). It did not do something to itself (organized myself).

190.description: Correct: That hat doesn't fit me because it is too small. Incorrect: That had didn't fit me because it is too small. Everything that happens in the present must be written in the present tense (doesn't fit me because it is too small). For things that happen in the past, everything must be written in the past tense. Lastly, everything that happens in the future must be written in the future tense.
190.title: Verb Tense Shift

128.title: Of vs. Off
128.description:
Of: a button of a coat, north of Chicago, member of a team. Off: turn off the lights, my shoes are off, break off some bread.
We use the word of to show how one thing is connected to another thing.
We use the word off to say that something is no longer connected to something else.

18.description:
Past: I walked to school. Present: I walk to school.
When we want to talk about things that happened earlier, we usually add ""ed"" to the end of regular verbs to make them past tense.
18.title: Past Tense

430.title: Practice: Adjectives and Adverbs
430.description:
Adjective: The park we visited was really beautiful. Adverb: You performed beautifully yesterday.
Adjectives (beautiful) are used to describe nouns (park).

456.description: Correct: We have made many mistakes before coming to the right conclusion. Incorrect: We have maked many mistakes before coming to the right conclusion. The past participle for ""make"" is made.
456.title: Made

446.description:
Separate: I am responsible for managing the team. Contraction: I'm responsible for managing the team.
The contraction for ""I am"" is made by writing I'm.
446.title: I'm, You're, Let's

304.description:
Incorrect: Did you get the email who I sent this morning? Correct: Did you get the email that I sent this morning?
We use that to give more details about an object (the email). Unlike ""which"", we use that when the details are are important to the meaning of the sentence (that I sent this morning). We usually don't place commas before that.
304.title: That

287.description:
Correct: Have you met the girl who started in grade 7 last week? Incorrect: Have you met the girl that started in grade 7 last week?
We use who to give more details about a person (the girl). Who is used for someone (the girl) who does an action (started in grade 7) instead of receiving an action.
287.title: Who

361.description:
Reflexive: My computer can shut itself off. Non-Reflexive: I can shut down my computer.
If an object (computer) does something to itself, we use a reflexive pronoun (itself). In the second example, the subject of the sentence (I) is shutting the computer down, and not shutting himself down, so we do not use a reflexive pronoun.
361.title: Itself

494.title: First Word of a Sentence
494.description:
Correct: You should climb Mount Washington. Incorrect: you should climb Mount Washington.
Whenever we begin a new sentence, we always capitalize the first letter of the first word (You) of the sentence.

375.description:
Close by: This picture here is crooked. Further away: That picture over there is crooked.
You use this and that when you are talking a single thing (a picture). You use this for things near you and that for things further away.
375.title: This & That

123.description:
Prepositional Adjective: The man behind the bench is waiting for the bus.
An adjective prepositional phrase describes what something looks like. Adjective prepositional phrases (behind the bench) are placed after a noun (man).
123.title: Prepositional Phrases: Adjective

376.description:
Close by: This picture here is crooked. Further away: That picture over there is crooked.
You use this and that when you are talking a single thing (a picture). You use this for things near you and that for things further away.
376.title: This & That

513.title: Practice: Capitalizing Dates and Names of People
513.description:
Correct: My birthday is on Wednesday, May 4th, 1994. Incorrect: My birthday is on wednesday, may 4th, 1994.
We capitalize the names of specific days and months (Wednesday, May).

329.title: Practice: Better & Best, Worse & Worst
329.description: Correct: Who here is the best at playing chess? Incorrect: Who here is the goodest at playing chess? The comparative adjective for ""good"" is better. The superlative adjective for ""good"" is best.

298.description:
Correct: Let's go to the living room, where we will serve drinks. Incorrect: Let's go to the living room, when we will serve drinks.
Where is used to talk about something happening (serve drinks) in, on, or at a certain place (living room).
298.title: Where

259.description: Not only, but also: He was not only an excellent athlete, but also a great musician. And: He was an excellent athlete and a great musician. We use not only and but also to connect two different ideas to something. We always place a comma before but also in these kinds of sentences. Not only is usually placed before one idea, while but also is used instead of the word ""and.""
259.title: Not Only ... But Also

432.title: Adjectives to Adverbs: Consonant Ending
432.description:
Adjective: Careful, that knife is sharp. Adverb: I sharply turned the car around.
If an adjective ends in a consonant (sharp), then we usually add ""ly"" onto the end of the adjective to make it an adverb (sharply).

138.description:
Correct: I will conduct the meeting. Incorrect: Me will conduct the meeting. Also Incorrect: Mine will conduct the meeting.
Subject pronouns (I) are words like ""I,"" ""you,"" ""he,"" ""she,"" ""it,"" ""we,"" ""you,"" and ""they."" They are usually near the front of the sentence and go before the verb.
138.title: Subjective Pronouns

429.description:
Adjective: The park we visited was really beautiful. Adverb: You performed beautifully yesterday.
Adjectives (beautiful) are used to describe nouns (park).
429.title: Adjectives

343.title: Practice: Sat, Hid
343.description:
Correct: Everyone sat quietly while they waited to board the plane. Incorrect: Everyone sitted quietly while they waited to board the plane.
The past tense of ""sit"" is sat.

325.title: Adjectives Ending in ""y""
325.description: Correct: Papayas are considered to be healthier than bananas. Incorrect: Papayas are considered to be healthyer than bananas. To make an adjective ending in ""y"" (healthy) comparative, we change the ""y"" to an ""ier"" to the end of the word (**healthier**).

350.title: Saw
350.description:
Correct: We saw a wild boar the other day in the woods. Incorrect: We seen a wild boar the other day in the woods.
The past tense of ""see"" is saw.

294.title: Whom
294.description:
Correct: My father, whom I respect, is a self-made man. Incorrect: My father, who I respect, is a self-made man.
We use whom to give more details about someone (My father) who receives an action (I respect) instead of doing an action. The example above says that someone (I) respects her father, which means that ""father"" receives the action, ""respect"".

395.title: Practice: Man, Woman
395.description:
Correct: Are you mice, or are you men? Incorrect: Are you mice, or are you mans?
The word ""man"" has an irregular plural form. To make it plural, we change the ""a"" (man) to an ""e"" (men).

391.description:
Correct: Some people say cats have nine lives. Incorrect: Some people say cats have nine lifes.
Nouns that end in ""fe"" (life) have an irregular plural form. To make them plural, we change the ""fe"" (life) to ""ves"" (lives).
391.title: rregular Plural Nouns Practice: Ending With ""F,"" ""Fe,"" and ""O.""

2.description: It's: It's a nice day. Its: The dog wags its tail. It's is the same as ""it is"". Its means the object (tail) belongs to the subject (dog).
2.title: It's vs. Its

127.title: Its vs. It's
127.description:
It's: It's time to go. Its: The dog wags its tail.
It's is the same as ""it is"".
Its is possessive, meaning the object (tail) belongs to the subject (dog).

399.description:
Correct: Did you know great white sharks lose hundreds of teeth every year? Incorrect: Did you know great white sharks lose hundreds of tooths every year?
The word ""tooth"" has an irregular plural form, similar to the word ""foot"". To make it plural, we change the double ""o"" (tooth) into a double ""e"" (teeth).
399.title: Tooth vs. Teeth

169.description: Niether … nor: My friend is neither snowboarding nor skiing today. Either … or: My friend is either snowboarding or skiing today. Neither and nor are used the same way as the words ""either"" and ""or"". However, neither and nor are used for negative sentences.
169.title: Neither ... Nor

470.title: Using Periods
470.description:
Correct: I went to the zoo. I saw an elephant. Incorrect: I went to the zoo.I saw an elephant. Incorrect: I went to the zoo .I saw an elephant.
We put a space after a period.

93.title: Product Names
93.description:
Correct: My favorite baseball team is the Yankees. Incorrect: My favorite baseball team is the yankees.
We capitalize all product names. Product names include companies (Microsoft), sports teams (Yankees), and brand names (Coca-Cola).

417.title: Use Collective Nouns-3
417.description:
Correct: There are 12 diapers in a pack. Incorrect: There are 12 diapers in a pack.
Pack is a collective noun that can have many different meanings. It can be a group of things packaged together, for example, soda, gum, or candy. It can also refer to groups of animals that live together, especially wolves.

36.title: At (Place)
36.description:
Correct: Lots of people wait at the bus stop. Incorrect: Lots of people wait in the bus stop.
We use at to talk about exact locations, like at the bus stop, or at home.

404.title: Practice: Mice, Goose, Deer
404.description:
Correct: I think there are some mice living in the walls. Incorrect: I think there are some mouses living in the walls.
The word ""mouse"" has an irregular plural form. To make it plural, we change the ""ouse"" (mouse) to ""ice"" (mice).

320.description:
Simple Past: James cleaned the mess he made when his mom walked in the room. Past Progressive: James was cleaning the mess he made when his mom walked in the room.
Past progressive tense describes something which was happening (was cleaning) when something else occurred (mom walked in). This tense is made by putting words like""am"", ""is"", and ""are"" before the verb, and adding ""ing"" at the end of the verb (was cleaning).
320.title: Past Progressive

135.description:
Correct: We heard a booming voice shout, ""Who are you?"" Incorrect: We heard a booming voice shout, ""who are you?""
When we use quotations in a sentence, we always capitalize the first letter of the first word (Who) of the quote as though it was starting a new sentence.
135.title: Quotations

58.description:
Correct: I think there are some mice living in the walls. Incorrect: I think there are some mouses living in the walls.
The word ""mouse"" has an irregular plural form. To make it plural, we change the ""ouse"" (mouse) to ""ice"" (mice).
58.title: Mouse vs. Mice

306.description:
Correct: Please tell me why you missed the meeting. Incorrect: Please tell me where you missed the meeting.
Why is used to talk about something happening (missed the meeting) for a certain reason.
306.title: Why

250.title: Practice: Parallel Structure
250.description: Correct: I laughed, I cried, and I shouted during the performance. Incorrect: I laughed, I was crying, and I shout during the performance. Sentences flow easily when all the actions in a list have the same ending. This means that each and every action in a list stays in the past, present, or future tense.

60.description:
Singular: I saw a deer crossing the road earlier. Plural: I saw ten deer crossing the road earlier.
The word ""deer"" does not change when it becomes plural.
60.title: Deer

409.title: Common Nouns
409.description:
Examples: man, woman, city, country, baseball team.
Common nouns are ordinary words for people, places, and things, such as man, or country. Common nouns are not capitalized.

119.description:
Permission: May we go to the park tomorrow? I really want to go! Ability: Can we go to the park tomorrow? Do we have enough time?
We use may to ask or give permission. We use can to say we have the ability to do something.
119.title: Can vs. May

458.title: Regular Past Participles
458.description: With a Helping Verb: I have walked to the library before. As an Adjective: Gene had chilled fruit with his lunch. Regular past participles are made by adding ""ed"" to the end of the verbs. We use the past participle with helping verbs like ""have"" or ""had"" (I have walked). Past participles can also be used as adjectives when they come before nouns (chilled fruit), or when they follow the verb ""be"".

5.description: A: I climbed a tree. An: I climbed an oak tree. Articles (a, an) are used before nouns (tree, oak tree). We use ""a"" before nouns that start with a consonant sound (everything but a, e, i, o, u). We use ""an"" before nouns that start with vowel sounds (a, e, i, o, u).
5.title: Articles: A, An

199.description: The word although means ""even though"" or ""in spite of the fact that."" It is a subordinating conjunction. Make sure you spell this as one word: although (not ""all though"").
199.title: Although

120.title: Should vs. Must
120.description:
Advice: You should go to the doctor. Emergency: You must go to the doctor.
We use the word must when we want to emphasize that something needs to be done. We use should when we want to suggest or give advice.

80.title: Spoke
80.description:
Correct: That lady spoke to me in a nasty tone. Incorrect: That lady speaked to me in a nasty tone.
The past tense of ""speak"" is spoke.

255.title: Practice: Pronoun Shift
255.description:
Correct: If they stay in touch, most people will have a lot of options available to them. Incorrect: If you stay in touch, most people will have a lot of options available to them.
Pronouns need to stay the same in gender (she, he) and number (they, them). This means that if the subject is plural (they), then any pronouns referring to it will usually be plural as well (them).

434.title: Adjectives to Adverbs: Ending in ""y""
434.description:
Adjective: I was really happy this morning. Adverb: I will happily go out tonight.
Adjectives ending in ""y"" (happy), become adverbs by changing the ""y"" to an ""i"", and then adding ""ly""(happily).

305.title: That
305.description:
Incorrect: Did you get the email who I sent this morning? Correct: Did you get the email that I sent this morning?
We use that to give more details about an object (the email). Unlike ""which"", we use that when the details are are important to the meaning of the sentence (that I sent this morning). We usually don't place commas before that.

86.description:
Adjective: My car is really slow. Adverb: I drive slowly when it is raining.
Adverbs are used to describe verbs, adjectives, or other adverbs. They usually describe how an action is being done (drive slowly).
86.title: Adverbs

389.title: Change Sentences from Passive to Active-1
389.description:
Passive Voice: The sausage (subject) was eaten (verb) by Ryan.
Active Voice: Ryan (subject) ate (verb) the sausage.
To change a sentence from the passive voice to the active voice, you must change the subject so that instead of the verb being done to it, the subject does the verb.

157.description: Correct: Papayas are considered to be healthier than bananas. Incorrect: Papayas are considered to be healthyer than bananas. To make an adjective ending in ""y"" (healthy) comparative, we change the ""y"" to an ""ier"" to the end of the word (**healthier**).
157.title: Adjectives Ending in ""y""

179.description: With a Helping Verb: I have walked to the library before. As an Adjective: Gene had chilled fruit with his lunch. Regular past participles are made by adding ""ed"" to the end of the verbs. We use the past participle with helping verbs like ""have"" or ""had"" (I have walked). Past participles can also be used as adjectives when they come before nouns (chilled fruit), or when they follow the verb ""be"".
179.title: Regular Past Participles

175.description: With Meanwhile: I was cleaning the whole house. Meanwhile, my brother was still sleeping. Without Meanwhile: I was cleaning the whole house. My brother was still sleeping. We use meanwhile at the beginning of a sentence to say two events are happening at the same time. We place a comma after meanwhile (Meanwhile, my brother was still sleeping).
175.title: Meanwhile

225.description:
The happy young couple lived happily ever after, or so they thought...
is always written with a space between the two words. ""Everafter"" is just a misspelling of ever after.
225.title: Vocabulary: Ever after

478.description: Correct: If I were you, I wouldn't drive down this road at night. Incorrect: If I was you, I wouldn't drive down this road at night. When we wish for something, or wonder if something could happen, we use ""were"" instead of ""was"". If it is something that could or has been true, we use ""was"" instead of were.
478.title: Verb Mood Shift

7.title: Irregular Verbs in the Past Tense: Find
7.description: Incorrect: I finally finded my phone in my backpack. Correct: I finally found my phone in my backpack. The past tense of ""find"" is found.

497.title: Quotations
497.description:
Correct: We heard a booming voice shout, ""Who are you?"" Incorrect: We heard a booming voice shout, ""who are you?""
When we use quotations in a sentence, we always capitalize the first letter of the first word (Who) of the quote as though it was starting a new sentence.

321.description:
Simple Future: Alice will watch TV when her mother comes home. Future Progressive: Alice will be watching TV when her mother comes home.
Future progressive tense describes an ongoing action (watching tv) that will take place in the future (when her mother comes home). This tense is made by putting words like ""am"", ""is"", and ""are"" before the verb, and adding ""ing"" to the end of the verb (will be watching).
321.title: Future Progressive

492.description: Correct: This box has books, magazines, and newspaper articles. Incorrect: This box has books magazines and newspaper articles. We place commas after each item in a list (books, magazines,). We finish a list by placing the word ""and"" before the last item.
492.title: Practice: Colons and Commas in a List

412.description: Example: My father's stamp collection is huge. Example: The ship's sails were filled with a gust of wind. Possessive nouns are used to show ownership. To make most common or proper nouns possessive, we add an apostrophe and an ""s"" to the end of the word.
412.title: Possessive Nouns

107.description:
Correct: Have you met the girl who started in grade 7 last week? Incorrect: Have you met the girl that started in grade 7 last week?
We use who to give more details about a person (the girl). Who is used for someone (the girl) who does an action (started in grade 7) instead of receiving an action.
107.title: Who

284.title: Your vs. You're
284.description:
Your: I need to borrow your umbrella. You're: I hope that you're going to lend me one.
We use your when something belongs to you. You're means you are.

96.title: Can't
96.description:
Separate: I can not see in the dark. Contraction: I can't see in the dark.
To make ""can"" and ""not"" a contraction, we write can't.

35.title: At (Time)
35.description:
Correct: I will meet my friend at noon. Incorrect: I will meet my friend on noon.
We use the preposition at for specific times, like 1:30 PM or 7:00 AM.

368.description:
Correct: Lots of people wait at the bus stop. Incorrect: Lots of people wait in the bus stop.
We use at to talk about exact locations, like at the bus stop, or at home.
368.title: Practice: At, In, On (Place)

500.title: Practice: Possessive Nouns
500.description:
Correct: I think that is Jane's notebook. Incorrect: That is Janes notebook.
Possessive nouns are used to show ownership of the noun written after it (Jane's notebook). Singular possessive nouns are usually made by adding an apostrophe and an ""s"" to the end of the word.

270.description:
Lose: lose my keys, lose a game, lose one's balance. Loose: the screws were loose, it broke loose.
We use lose when we can't find something, don't have something, or didn't win.
We use loose when something isn't tight, or something is freed.
270.title: Practice: Lose, Loose

288.description:
Correct: Let's go to the living room, where we will serve drinks. Incorrect: Let's go to the living room, when we will serve drinks.
Where is used to talk about something happening (serve drinks) in, on, or at a certain place (living room).
288.title: Where

77.title: Hid
77.description:
Correct: Janice hid a note in my backpack. Incorrect: Janice hided a note in my backpack.
The past tense of ""hide"" is hid.

153.description:
Correct: Victor, Lucas, and Don play basketball. Incorrect: Victor,Lucas,and Don play basketball. Incorrect: Victor ,Lucas ,and Don play basketball.
We put a space after a comma. We do not put a space before a comma.
153.title: Using Commas

229.description: Correct: All the kids splashing around in the pool laughed without a care in the world. Incorrect: All the kids' splashing around in the pool laughed without a care in the world. Plural words that do not own something are written without an apostrophe. Words with an apostrophe at the end are plural possessive words, and own something.
229.title: Plural vs. Plural Possessive

79.description:
Correct: I made a vase out of clay. Incorrect: I maked a vase out of clay.
The past tense of ""make"" is made.
79.title: Made

508.description:
Correct: I am moving to Los Angeles next month. Incorrect: I am moving to los angeles next month.
We capitalize the names of all geographic places (cities, countries, towns, mountains, etc).
508.title: Geographic Names

324.description: Correct: James is the tallest guy in school. Incorrect: James is the most tall guy in school. Superlative adjectives tell us how one thing (James) is the ""most"" or ""least"". Regular superlative adjectives are formed by adding ""est"" to the end of a word (**tallest**).
324.title: Superlative Adjectives

139.description:
Correct: Will you please call her when you finish the poster? Incorrect: Will you please call she when you finish the poster? Also Incorrect: Will you please call hers when you finish the poster?
Object pronouns (her) are words like ""me"", ""you"", ""him"", ""her"", ""it"", ""us"", and ""them"". Object pronouns go after the verb (call).
139.title: Object Pronouns

147.description:
Vague: Mary orchestrated tonight's show and has a nice singing voice. It is just one of her many talents. Specific: Mary orchestrated tonight's show and has a nice singing voice. Her singing voice is just one of her many talents.
In the first example, it is not clear whether it refers to Mary's signing voice or to Mary's orchestration of the concert.
In the second sentence, it is replaced with her singing voice. It is now clear that Mary's talent is her singing voice.
147.title: Vague Pronouns: One Subject

260.title: Pracitce: Not Only, But Also; Both, And
260.description: Not only … but also: He was not only an excellent athlete, but also a great musician. And: He was an excellent athlete and a great musician. We use not only and but also to connect two different ideas to something. We always place a comma before but also in these kinds of sentences. Not only is usually placed before one idea, while but also is used instead of the word ""and"".

88.description:
Adjective: I was really happy this morning. Adverb: I will happily go out tonight.
Adjectives ending in ""y"" (happy), become adverbs by changing the ""y"" to an ""i"", and then adding ""ly""(happily).
88.title: Adjectives to Adverbs: Ending in ""y""

344.title: Sat
344.description:
Correct: Everyone sat quietly while they waited to board the plane. Incorrect: Everyone sitted quietly while they waited to board the plane.
The past tense of ""sit"" is sat.

438.description:
Separate: I can not see in the dark. Contraction: I can't see in the dark.
To make ""can"" and ""not"" a contraction, we write can't.
438.title: Can't

64.description:
Reflexive: Steven sees himself becoming team captain one day. Non-Reflexive: I see Steven becoming team captain one day.
If a male subject (Steven) does something to himself, we use a reflexive pronoun (himself). In the second example, the subject (I) is seeing someone else, so we do not use a reflexive pronoun.
64.title: Himself

311.title: Which
311.description:
That: The new classrooms that had their walls painted look great. Which: The new classrooms, which had their walls painted, look great.
We use which to give more details about something (new classrooms), but the details don't change the meaning of the sentence. In the first example, using ""that"" means only the painted classrooms look great. In the second example, using which means that the new classrooms look great, and they also happen to be painted. We usually place commas before which.

510.description:
Correct: August 30th, 1972 Incorrect: 1972, 30th, August
When we write dates, we start with the month (August), then the day (30th), and end with the year (1972). We also put a comma in between the day and the year (August 30th, 1972).
510.title: Practice: Use Commas for Dates and Lists

132.title: There, They're, & Their
132.description:
There: There is a park by the lake. They're: They're going to the park. Their: They left their frisbee at the park.
There is used for locations.
They're is the same as ""they are"".
Their is used when something (they) owns something else (frisbee).

301.title: Who
301.description:
Correct: Have you met the girl who started in grade 7 last week? Incorrect: Have you met the girl that started in grade 7 last week?
We use who to give more details about a person (the girl). Who is used for someone (the girl) who does an action (started in grade 7) instead of receiving an action.

155.title: Using Periods with Numbers
155.description:
Correct: They hiked 1.7 miles. Incorrect: They hiked 1. 7 miles.
We do not put a space before or after a period when we are writing numbers.

237.description: Correct: After the meal was finished, I asked, ""May I be excused?"" Incorrect: After the meal was finished, I asked ""May I be excused?"" When we write quotations after a speaking verb, we place a comma at the end of the speaking verb (asked,).
237.title: Commas before Quotations

473.title: Using Commas with Numbers
473.description:
Correct: 1,500,000 Incorrect: 1, 500, 000
We do not put a space before or after a comma when we are writing numbers.

495.description:
Correct: You should climb Mount Washington. Incorrect: you should climb Mount Washington.
Whenever we begin a new sentence, we always capitalize the first letter of the first word (You) of the sentence.
495.title: Practice: Correct Capitalization

400.description:
Correct: Where are the children playing right now? Incorrect: Where are the childs playing right now?
The word ""child"" has an irregular plural form. To make it plural, we add ""ren"" to the end (children).
400.title: Child vs. Children

202.title: Pour, Poor
202.description: Pour is a verb. It can take an object (She poured some juice into the glass), or it can be intransitive (Water poured from the roof, making a big puddle on the ground). Poor is an adjective that can refer to someone or something that lacks money, or it can refer to someone or something that is unfortunate or deficient in some other way.

45.title: Writing the Date
45.description:
Correct: August 30th, 1972 Incorrect: 1972, 30th, August
When we write dates, we start with the month (August), then the day (30th), and end with the year (1972). We also put a comma in between the day and the year (August 30th, 1972).

512.title: Capitalization: Dates
512.description:
Correct: My birthday is on Wednesday, May 4th, 1994. Incorrect: My birthday is on wednesday, may 4th, 1994.
We capitalize the names of specific days and months (Wednesday, May).

340.description:
Correct: My brother wrote me an email, but I never received it. Incorrect: My brother writed me an email, but I never received it.
The past tense of """"write"""" is wrote.
340.title: Wrote

421.title: Future Tense
421.description:
Future: I will walk to school. Present: I walk to school.
We use the future tense to describe things that we think will happen. To make the future tense ( will walk ), we add the helping verb ""will"" before the verb ( walk ).

160.title: Better & Best
160.description: Correct: Who here is the best at playing chess? Incorrect: Who here is the goodest at playing chess? The comparative adjective for ""good"" is better. The superlative adjective for ""good"" is best.

66.title: Itself
66.description:
Reflexive: My computer can shut itself off. Non-Reflexive: I can shut down my computer.
If an object (computer) does something to itself, we use a reflexive pronoun (itself). In the second example, the subject of the sentence (I) is shutting the computer down, and not shutting himself down, so we do not use a reflexive pronoun.

54.title: Man vs. Men
54.description:
Correct: Are you mice, or are you men? Incorrect: Are you mice, or are you mans?
The word ""man"" has an irregular plural form. To make it plural, we change the ""a"" (man) to an ""e"" (men).

144.description:
Correct: A doctor has an important job because she saves lives. Correct: A doctor has an important job because he saves lives. Incorrect: A doctor has an important job because they save lives.
Pronouns need to stay the same in gender (she, he) and number (they, them). This means that if the subject is singular (doctor), then any pronouns referring to it will will usually be singular as well (he, she).
144.title: Pronoun Shift: Singular

209.description:
Lose: lose my keys, lose a game, lose one's balance. Loose: the screws were loose, it broke loose.
We use lose when we can't find something, don't have something, or didn't win.
We use loose when something isn't tight, or something is freed.
209.title: Loose, Lose

424.description:
Not Connected: I like spaghetti. I like hamburgers. Connected: I like spaghetti and I like hamburgers.
And connects two sentences into one longer sentence. In the example, we use and to show that the subject ( I ) likes both spaghetti and hamburgers.
424.title: Practice: And, Or

490.description: Correct: Can we go, Paul? Incorrect: Can we go Paul? Correct: Sarah, you should go to practice. Incorrect: Sarah you should go to practice. If we address somebody at the end of a sentence, we place a comma before their name. If we address somebody at the beginning of a sentence we place a comma after their name.
490.title: Addressing People

130.description:
Lose: lose my keys, lose a game, lose one's balance. Loose: the screws were loose, it broke loose.
We use lose when we can't find something, don't have something, or didn't win.
We use loose when something isn't tight, or something is freed.
130.title: Lose vs. Loose

427.title: Practice: So, Because
427.description:
Not Connected: I don't like hamburgers. I will have spaghetti. Connected: I don't like hamburgers, so I will have spaghetti.
So connects two related sentences into one larger one. In the example, so is used because the subject (I) does not like hamburgers, and has spaghetti instead.

100.title: I've
100.description:
Separate: I have been to Mexico before. Contraction: I've been to Mexico before.
To make a contraction with ""I"" and ""have"", we write I've.

367.title: At (Place)
367.description:
Correct: Lots of people wait at the bus stop. Incorrect: Lots of people wait in the bus stop.
We use at to talk about exact locations, like at the bus stop, or at home.

218.description: My family raised a litter of cats and then put them up for adoption. The demolition crew razed the old office building to the ground. Raised is the past tense form of the verb ""to raise"" which can mean either lifting something up (raise the bar) or to rear a living thing (raise a litter of cats). Razed is the past tense form of the verb ""to raze"" which means to level a building to the ground by completely destroying or burning the structure.
218.title: Vocabulary: Raised vs Razed

327.title: Adjectives ending in ""y"" (Superlative)
327.description: Correct: Are papayas the healthiest fruit of all? Incorrect: Are papayas the healthyest fruitof all? To make an adjective ending in ""y"" (healthy) superlative, we change the ""y"" to an ""iest"" to the end of the word (**healthiest**).

30.description:
Indefinite Article: There is lots of pizza. I ate a slice. Definite Article: There was a loaded slice of bacon pizza. I ate the slice.
You use a definite article (the) to specify something (the slice of bacon pizza). You use an indefinite article (a, an) when you have not specified something (a slice).
30.title: The

57.description:
Correct: Did you know great white sharks lose hundreds of teeth every year? Incorrect: Did you know great white sharks lose hundreds of tooths every year?
The word ""tooth"" has an irregular plural form, similar to the word ""foot"". To make it plural, we change the double ""o"" (tooth) into a double ""e"" (teeth).
57.title: Tooth vs. Teeth

377.description:
Indefinite Article: There is lots of pizza. I ate a slice. Definite Article: There was a loaded slice of bacon pizza. I ate the slice.
You use a definite article (the) to specify something (the slice of bacon pizza). You use an indefinite article (a, an) when you have not specified something (a slice).
377.title: Practice: A, An, The

504.description: Correct: A wise man one said, ""Doubt everything, find your own light."" Incorrect: A wise man once said ""Doubt everything, find your own light. We use a pair of quotation marks to show that someone is speaking. Whenever we use quotation marks, we always put a comma before the beginning of the quote (said,).
504.title: Practice: Commas and Quotation Marks in Dialogue

300.title: Who
300.description:
Correct: Have you met the girl who started in grade 7 last week? Incorrect: Have you met the girl that started in grade 7 last week?
We use who to give more details about a person (the girl). Who is used for someone (the girl) who does an action (started in grade 7) instead of receiving an action.

347.title: Practice: Knew, Made, Became
347.description:
Correct: In middle school, Lisa knew more about animals than anyone else. Incorrect: In middle school, Lisa knowed more about animals than anyone else.
The past tense of ""know"" is knew.

286.description:
That: The new classrooms that had their walls painted look great. Which: The new classrooms, which had their walls painted, look great.
We use which to give more details about something (new classrooms), but the details don't change the meaning of the sentence. In the first example, using ""that"" means only the painted classrooms look great. In the second example, using which means that the new classrooms look great, and they also happen to be painted. We usually place commas before which.
286.title: Which

223.title: Vocabulary: Quiet vs Quite
223.description:
During study hours, the library was so quiet you could hear people turning the pages of their books. It was quite a shock when Marty managed to make it home for Christmas.
Quiet is an adjective that means soft or silent. Quite is an adjective that means ""to a noticeable degree or extent.""

420.title: Practice: Past Tense Verbs
420.description:
Past: I walked to school. Present: I walk to school.
When we want to talk about things that happened earlier, we usually add ""ed"" to the end of regular verbs to make them past tense.

227.description:
Incorrect: The fox quickly digged a hole in the snow to keep warm. Correct: The fox quickly dug a hole in the snow to keep warm.
The past tense of ""dig"" is dug.
227.title: Dug

200.description:
The word please can be a verb meaning ""to satisfy, to delight,"" or it can be an interjection that signals a polite request.
A plea (noun) is an urgent request or an emotional appeal. It can also refer to a legal claim, as when an accused person makes a plea of ""guilty"" or ""not guilty"" in court. The plural form of the noun is pleas.
200.title: Please, Pleas

418.description:
Correct: There is a huge group of people at the front gate. Incorrect: There is a huge bunch of people at the front gate.
Group is a collective noun that usually refers to a number of people or objects that are nearby or considered together as one unit. For example, a group of students, a group of packages, a group of fruits, etc...
418.title: Use Collective Nouns-4

172.title: Colons
172.description: Correct: The box was filled with stuff: two pairs of shoes, some keys, and a cup. Incorrect: The box has: two pairs of shoes, some keys, and a cup. We use colons (filled with stuff:) to begin a list. Colons can only be used after complete sentences. Colons are never placed after main verb of the sentence they are added too. After the colon begins the list, we place commas after each item in the list.

380.description:
Close by: These shoes are dirty. Further away: Those dogs are cute.
You use these and those when you are talking about more than one thing. You use these for things near you and those for things further away.
380.title: These & Those

70.title: Became
70.description:
Correct: After three years of practice, I became a skillful archer. Incorrect: After three years of practice, I becomed a skillful archer.
The past tense of ""become"" is became.

355.description:
Reflexive: I hit myself with a ball playing soccer yesterday. Non-Reflexive: I was hit with a ball while playing soccer yesterday.
If a subject (I) does something to itself, we use a reflexive pronoun (myself). In the second example, the subject (I) does not do something to itself, so we do not use a reflexive pronoun.
355.title: Practice: Myself, Yourself

37.description:
Correct: I will meet my cousin in the fall. Incorrect: I will meet my cousin at the fall.
We use in for months, seasons, and times of day, like October, winter or morning.
37.title: In (Time)

210.description:
To: I sent an email to you. Too: Brett sent you an email too. Two: Pat sent you not one, but two emails.
To is used mostly to show where something is moving.
Too can either mean ""also"" or ""excessive"". Two is the number after ""one"".
210.title: To, Too & Two

386.title: Change Sentences from Active to Passive-1
386.description:
Active Voice: Tom (subject) shipped (verb) the package.
Passive Voice: The passage (subject) was shipped (verb) by Tom.
To change a sentence from the active voice to the passive voice, you must change the subject so that instead of doing the verb, the verb is being done to it.

112.description:
Correct: My favorite time of year is autumn, when all the leaves change color. Incorrect: My favorite time of year is autumn, where all the leaves change color.
When is used to to talk about something happening (leaves change color) in on, or at a certain time (autumn).
112.title: When

38.title: In (Place)
38.description:
Correct: I had a great time in London. Incorrect: I had a great time at London.
We use in when we are inside or within a place, like in France, or in a car.

297.title: Which
297.description:
That: The new classrooms that had their walls painted look great. Which: The new classrooms, which had their walls painted, look great.
We use which to give more details about something (new classrooms), but the details don't change the meaning of the sentence. In the first example, using ""that"" means only the painted classrooms look great. In the second example, using which means that the new classrooms look great, and they also happen to be painted. We usually place commas before which.

425.title: Or
425.description:
Not Connected: Would you like spaghetti? Would you like a hamburger? Connected: Would you like spaghetti, or would you like a hamburger?
Or connects two sentences into one longer sentence. In the example, or is used to show a choice between spaghetti or a hamburger.

484.title: Practice: Subjective, Objective, and Possessive Pronouns
484.description:
Correct: I will conduct the meeting. Incorrect: Me will conduct the meeting. Also Incorrect: Mine will conduct the meeting.
Subject pronouns (I) are words like ""I,"" ""you,"" ""he,"" ""she,"" ""it,"" ""we,"" ""you,"" and ""they."" They are usually near the front of the sentence and go before the verb.

290.description:
Correct: My friend Steve, whose job is fun, loves going to work. Incorrect: My friend Steve, who job is fun, loves going to work.
We use whose to give more details about something the subject (Steve) owns (job).
290.title: Whose

234.title: Quotations Come in Pairs
234.description: Correct: The instructions say, ""Turning the screws clockwise makes them tighter."" Incorrect: The instructions say, ""Turning the screws clockwise makes them tighter. We write quotation marks at the beginning and the end of a quotation.

193.title: Using Quill
193.description: Correct: A crafty smile flitted across the shrew's rugged face. Incorrect: a crafty smile flitted across the shrew's rugged face We always capitalize the first letter of the first word of a sentence (A). We end our sentences with proper punctuation: a period, a question mark, or an exclamation mark (face.).

493.title: Colons
493.description: Correct: The box was filled with stuff: two pairs of shoes, some keys, and a cup. Incorrect: The box has: two pairs of shoes, some keys, and a cup. We use colons (filled with stuff:) to begin a list. Colons can only be used after complete sentences. Colons are never placed after main verb of the sentence they are added too. After the colon begins the list, we place commas after each item in the list.

222.title: Vocabulary: Mary vs Marry
222.description: ""I refuse to marry!"" said the woman to her father. ""I saw Mary the other day at the supermarket."" Marry is a verb which means ""to wed"". Mary is a name, and therefore is a proper noun. As a result, Mary is always capitalized.

75.title: Ate
75.description:
Correct: I once ate three hot dogs at the same time. Incorrect: I once eated three hot dogs at the same time.
The past tense of ""eat"" is ate.

184.title: Gone
184.description: Correct: Velma has gone to visit her brother in the hospital. Incorrect: Velma has goed to visit her brother in the hospital. The past participle of ""go"" is gone.

103.title: I'm
103.description:
Separate: I am responsible for managing the team. Contraction: I'm responsible for managing the team.
The contraction for ""I am"" is made by writing I'm.

339.title: Went
339.description:
Correct: My friends and I went shopping an hour ago. Incorrect: My friends and I goed shopping an hour ago.
The past tense of ""go"" is went.

498.title: Addresses
498.description:
Correct: I live on 15 Deepwood Rd in Hartford CT. Incorrect: I live on 15 deepwood rd in hartford ct.
The names of roads, towns, and states in addresses are all proper nouns, so they are capitalized. Don't forget to capitalize all the proper nouns in your address whenever you write it down.

186.description: Correct: The drawing on the refrigerator was done by my son. Incorrect: The drawing was done by my son on the refrigerator. It is best to describe everything about something (drawing on the refrigerator) before mentioning other people or things related to it (done by my son). The first example mentions a drawing that is on the refrigerator, while the second example shows an odd situation where the son was on top of the refrigerator.
186.title: Misplaced Modifiers

11.description:
Examples: John, Sarah, London, Japan, and Yankees
Proper nouns are names for people, places, and things, such as John, or Japan. All proper nouns are capitalized.
11.title: Proper Nouns

499.title: Singular Possessive
499.description:
Correct: I think that is Jane's notebook. Incorrect: That is Janes notebook.
Possessive nouns are used to show ownership of the noun written after it (Jane's notebook). Singular possessive nouns are usually made by adding an apostrophe and an ""s"" to the end of the word.

8.description: At: I will meet my friend at 2:30. In: I will meet my friend in the fall. On: I will meet my friend on Monday. We use at for specific times, like 1:30 PM or 7:00 AM. We use in for months, seasons, and times of day, like October, winter, or morning. We use on for days of the week and certain dates, like Monday or October 30th.
8.title: Prepositions (Time): At, In, On.

505.title: Holidays
505.description:
Correct: Which holiday is closest to today, Christmas, Hanukkah, Valentine's Day, or Easter? Incorrect: Which holiday is closest to today, christmas, hanukkah, valentines day, or easter?
When we write holiday names, we always capitalize the first letter of all the words (New Year's Eve, Christmas Day, Fourth of July).

457.description: Correct: Velma has gone to visit her brother in the hospital. Incorrect: Velma has goed to visit her brother in the hospital. The past participle of ""go"" is gone.
457.title: Gone

449.title: Haven't
449.description:
Separate: I have not contacted Mrs. Robinson. Contraction: I haven't contacted Mrs. Robinson.
To make ""have"" and ""not"" a contraction, we write haven't.

251.title: Verbs Ending in ""ing""
251.description: Correct: Marcus enjoys hiking, climbing, and canoeing. Incorrect: Marcus enjoys hiking, to climb, and canoes all the time. When writing a list of actions, the flow and rhythm of the sentence is improved if all the items in the list (hiking, climbing, and canoeing) are formed the same way. If one action in a list ends with ""ing,"" the others should as well.

491.title: Commas in a List
491.description: Correct: This box has books, magazines, and newspaper articles. Incorrect: This box has books magazines and newspaper articles. We place commas after each item in a list (books, magazines,). We finish a list by placing the word ""and"" before the last item.

266.title: Of vs. Off
266.description:
Of: a button of a coat, north of Chicago, member of a team. Off: turn off the lights, my shoes are off, break off some bread.
We use the word of to show how one thing is connected to another thing.
We use the word off to say that something is no longer connected to something else.

444.description:
Separate: It is really great you decided to come. Contraction: It's really great you decided to come.
To make a contraction with ""it"" and ""is"", we write it's.
444.title: It's

115.title: Present Progressive
115.description:
Simple Present: Jesse thinks about seagulls. Present Progressive: Jesse is thinking about seagulls right now.
Present progressive tense describes an ongoing action that is happening right now (Jesse is thinking right now). This tense is made by putting words like “am,” “is”, and “are” before the verb, and adding “ing” to the end of the verb (is thinking).

76.title: Went
76.description:
Correct: My friends and I went shopping an hour ago. Incorrect: My friends and I goed shopping an hour ago.
The past tense of ""go"" is went.

278.title: To, Too, & Two
278.description:
To: I sent an email to you. Too: Brett sent you an email too. Two: Pat sent you not one, but two emails.
To is used mostly to show where something is moving Too can either mean """"also"""" or """"excessive"""". Two is the number after """"one"""".

272.title: Than vs. Then
272.description:
Than: I am older than my brother. Then: The sky was pink, and then it became dark.
We use than to compare two or more things. We use then to say ""at that time.""

109.description:
Correct: My father, whom I respect, is a self-made man. Incorrect: My father, who I respect, is a self-made man.
We use whom to give more details about someone (My father) who receives an action (I respect) instead of doing an action. The example above says that someone (I) respects her father, which means that ""father"" receives the action, ""respect"".
109.title: Whom

69.description:
Reflexive: The models showed themselves off in various outfits. Non-Reflexive: The camera crew showed the models the pictures they took.
If the subject (models) does something to themselves, we use a reflexive pronoun (themselves). Sentences where the subject (crew) does not do something to itself do not need a reflexive pronoun.
69.title: Themselves

33.description:
Close by: These shoes are dirty. Further away: Those dogs are cute.
You use these and those when you are talking about more than one thing. You use these for things near you and those for things further away.
33.title: These & Those

191.title: Verb Mood Shift
191.description: Correct: If I were you, I wouldn't drive down this road at night. Incorrect: If I was you, I wouldn't drive down this road at night. When we wish for something, or wonder if something could happen, we use ""were"" instead of ""was"".

22.title: But
22.description:
Not Connected: I like spaghetti. I don’t like hamburgers. Connected: I like spaghetti, but I don’t like hamburgers.
But connects two contrasting sentences into one larger one. In the example, but is used to show that the subject (I) likes spaghetti, but not hamburgers.

445.title: Practice: Contractions
445.description:
Separate: I am responsible for managing the team. Contraction: I'm responsible for managing the team.
The contraction for ""I am"" is made by writing I'm.

346.title: Knew
346.description:
Correct: In middle school, Lisa knew more about animals than anyone else. Incorrect: In middle school, Lisa knowed more about animals than anyone else.
The past tense of ""know"" is knew.

337.description:
Correct: I'm glad you came to my party. Incorrect: I'm glad you comed to my party.
The past tense of ""come"" is came.
337.title: Practice: Came, Went, Did

205.title: Bear, Bare
205.description:
The verb bear means to carry, and bear can also be the name of an animal, e.g. polar bear, koala bear, panda bear, etc.
The adjective bare means that something is not clothed or covered; it can also refer to something that is empty. The word bare can also be a verb, meaning to uncover something or to expose something to view.

392.title: Ends with ""f""
392.description:
Correct: Two halves always make a whole. Incorrect: Two halfs always make a whole.
Nouns that end in ""f"" (half) have an irregular plural form. To make them plural, we change the ""f"" (half) to ""ves"" (halves).

319.title: Practice: Progressive Tense
319.description:
Simple Present: Jesse thinks about seagulls. Present Progressive: Jesse is thinking about seagulls right now.
Present progressive tense describes an ongoing action that is happening right now (Jesse is thinking right now). This tense is made by putting words like “am,” “is”, and “are” before the verb, and adding “ing” to the end of the verb (is thinking).

274.title: There, They're, & Their
274.description:
There: There is a park by the lake. They're: They're going to the park. Their: They left their frisbee at the park.
There is used for locations.
They're is the same as ""they are"".
Their is used when something (they) owns something else (frisbee).

295.description:
Correct: Please tell me why you missed the meeting. Incorrect: Please tell me where you missed the meeting.
Why is used to talk about something happening (missed the meeting) for a certain reason.
295.title: Why

163.title: Use Commas in Addresses
163.description: Correct: My address is 79 Brookfield Lane, Springfield, Massachusetts 01234. Incorrect: My address is 79 brookfield lane Springfield, Massachusetts, 01234. When we write out our addresses, we always put commas after the name of the street (Brookfield Lane,) and after the name of the city (Springfield). Remember to capitalize both the street and state names, because they are proper nouns.

471.title: Practice: Spaces with Punctuation
471.description:
Correct: I went to the zoo. I saw an elephant. Incorrect: I went to the zoo.I saw an elephant. Incorrect: I went to the zoo .I saw an elephant.
We put a space after a period.

159.title: Adjectives ending in ""y"" (Superlative)
159.description: Correct: Are papayas the healthiest fruit of all? Incorrect: Are papayas the healthyest fruitof all? To make an adjective ending in ""y"" (healthy) superlative, we change the ""y"" to an ""iest"" to the end of the word (**healthiest**).

316.description:
Correct: My favorite time of year is autumn, when all the leaves change color. Incorrect: My favorite time of year is autumn, where all the leaves change color.
When is used to to talk about something happening (leaves change color) in on, or at a certain time (autumn).
316.title: When

428.description:
Not Connected: I like this spaghetti. There is a lot of cheese in it. Connected: I like this spaghetti because there is a lot of cheese in it.
Because connects two sentences into one longer sentence. In the example, because is used to show that the amount of cheese is the reason the spaghetti is liked.
428.title: Because

371.title: A
371.description:
Incorrect: I climbed an tree. Correct: I climbed a tree.
Articles (a) are used before nouns (tree). The article an is used before nouns that start with vowel sounds (a, e, i, o, u).

78.title: Knew
78.description:
Correct: In middle school, Lisa knew more about animals than anyone else. Incorrect: In middle school, Lisa knowed more about animals than anyone else.
The past tense of ""know"" is knew.

402.title: Person vs. People
402.description:
Correct: I think we can fit at least three people in each room. Incorrect: I think we can fit at least three persons in each room.
The word ""person"" has an irregular plural form. To make it plural, we change the ""rson"" (person) to ""ople"" (people).

393.title: Ends with ""o""
393.description:
Correct: Do you know how many potatoes can fit in this sack? Incorrect: Do you know how many potatos can fit in this sack?
Nouns that end in ""o"" (potato) have an irregular plural form. To make them plural, we add an ""es"" to the end of the word (potatoes).

161.description: Correct: It is worse to have never tried than to fail. Incorrect: It is badder to have never tried than to fail. The comparative adjective for ""bad"" is worse. The superlative adjective for ""bad"" is worst.
161.title: Worse & Worst

479.title: Misplaced Modifiers
479.description: Correct: The drawing on the refrigerator was done by my son. Incorrect: The drawing was done by my son on the refrigerator. It is best to describe everything about something (drawing on the refrigerator) before mentioning other people or things related to it (done by my son). The first example mentions a drawing that is on the refrigerator, while the second example shows an odd situation where the son was on top of the refrigerator.""

441.description:
Separate: I have been to Mexico before. Contraction: I've been to Mexico before.
To make a contraction with ""I"" and ""have"", we write I've.
441.title: I've

197.description:
The verb throw has an irregular past tense form, threw, and an irregular participle form: thrown.
The noun throne is the ceremonial chair used by a king or some other ruler.
197.title: Thrown, Throne

502.description: Many Boys: Do not touch the boys' gear. One Boy: Do not touch the boy's gear. When multiple people or things own something we place an apostrophe after the ""s"" (boys'). When just one person or thing owns something we put the apostrophe before the ""s"".
502.title: Plural Possessive

71.description:
Correct: He broke my favorite cup. Incorrect: He breaked my favorite cup.
The past tense of ""break"" is broke.
71.title: Broke

268.title: Lose vs. Loose
268.description:
Lose: lose my keys, lose a game, lose one's balance. Loose: the screws were loose, it broke loose.
