We use lose when we can't find something, don't have something, or didn't win.
We use loose when something isn't tight, or something is freed.

308.title: Practice: Whose, Whom, Who
308.description:
Correct: Have you met the girl who started in grade 7 last week? Incorrect: Have you met the girl that started in grade 7 last week?
We use who to give more details about a person (the girl). Who is used for someone (the girl) who does an action (started in grade 7) instead of receiving an action.

435.title: Adjectives to Adverbs: Ending in ""le""
435.description:
Adjective: I think this task is pretty simple. Adverb: You simply put the ball in the net.
Adjectives ending in ""le"" (simple), become adverbs by changing the ""le"" to ""ly""(simply).

488.description: Positive: We are going to make it, aren't we? Negative: You aren't on my team, are you? Tag questions are little questions that we place at the end of sentences when we want to agree, disagree, or confirm what someone just said. If the first part of the sentence is positive (we are going to make it) then the tag question is negative (aren't we).
488.title: Practice: Commas for ""Yes"" and ""No,"" Tag Questions, and Addressing People

461.description: Correct: I have been in a band before. Incorrect: I have beed in a band before. The past participle for ""be"" is been.
461.title: Been

481.title: Intensive Pronouns vs. Reflexive Pronouns
481.description:
Intensive: I myself organized the meeting. Reflexive: I organized myself before going to the meeting.
Intensive Pronouns (myself) use the same words as reflexive pronouns (myself). However, when using intensive pronouns, the word emphasizes the the subject (I) emphasizes that it does something (organized the meeting). When the word is used as a reflexive pronoun, it emphasizes what the subject does to itself (organized myself).

113.description:
Correct: Please tell me why you missed the meeting. Incorrect: Please tell me where you missed the meeting.
Why is used to talk about something happening (missed the meeting) for a certain reason.
113.title: Why

95.title: Practice: Capitalize Holidays, Product Names, & Geographic Names

501.description: Correct: The saddles on each horse were both comfortable and stylish. Incorrect: The saddle's on each horse were both comfortable and stylish. Plural words that do not own something are written without an apostrophe. Words with an apostrophe placed before an ""s"" are singular possessive words.
501.title: Plural vs. Singular Possessive

341.description:
Correct: My brother wrote me an email, but I never received it. Incorrect: My brother writed me an email, but I never received it.
The past tense of ""write"" is wrote.
341.title: Practice: Wrote, Spoke

342.description:
Correct: That lady spoke to me in a nasty tone. Incorrect: That lady speaked to me in a nasty tone.
The past tense of """"speak"""" is spoke.
342.title: Spoke

455.description: Correct: My favorite team has lost only once this season. Incorrect: My favorite team has losed only once this season. The past participle for ""lose"" is lost.
455.title: Practice: Made, Lost, Gone

9.title: Lose vs. Loose
9.description: Lose: I lose my keys; I lose my balance. Loose: The screws were loose; It broke loose. Lose refers to a loss. Loose means to let go or the opposite of tight.

212.description:
There: There is a park by the lake. They're: They're going to the park. Their: They left their Frisbee at the park.
There is used for locations. They're is the same as ""they are"". Their is used when something (they) owns something else (frisbee).
212.title: There, Their, They're

134.description:
Correct: Do you have a class with Mr. Thompson? Incorrect: Do you have a class with mr. thompson?
We always capitalize the first letter of proper nouns (Mr. Thompson), which are people, places, and things, with names. We also capitalize any titles that might come before the proper noun, such as Mr., Ms., Dr., President, Professor, ect. Don't forget, ""I"" is a proper noun and is always capitalized.
134.title: Proper Nouns

257.description: Exactly Two Options: You can have either soup or salad. Two Options, Maybe More: You can have soup or salad. Whenever either is placed before or, we are presented with exactly two options (soup or salad). If the two options share a verb, either is written after the verb (have either). If the two options have different verbs, either is written before the first verb (either have).
257.title: Practice: Either, Or; Neither, Nor

509.description:
Correct: August 30th, 1972 Incorrect: 1972, 30th, August
When we write dates, we start with the month (August), then the day (30th), and end with the year (1972). We also put a comma in between the day and the year (August 30th, 1972).
509.title: Writing the Date

63.title: Yourself
63.description:
Reflexive: Why don't you lift yourself out of the hole? Non-Reflexive: Why don't you lift Alex out of the hole?
If a subject (you) does something to its itself, we use a reflexive pronoun (yourself). Sentences where the subject (you) does not do something to itself (Alex) do not use a reflexive pronoun.

406.description:
""Singular: I saw a deer crossing the road earlier. Plural: I saw ten deer crossing the road earlier.
The word """"deer"""" does not change when it becomes plural.
""
406.title: Deer

472.description:
Correct: Victor, Lucas, and Don play basketball. Incorrect: Victor,Lucas,and Don play basketball. Incorrect: Victor ,Lucas ,and Don play basketball.
We put a space after a comma. We do not put a space before a comma.
472.title: Using Commas

353.title: Found
353.description:
Correct: I finally found my phone in my backpack. Incorrect: I finally finded my phone in my backpack.
The past tense of ""find"" is found.

61.title: Sheep
61.description:
Singular: Do you own a sheep? Plural: Do you own three sheep?
The word ""sheep"" does not change when it becomes plural.

220.title: Vocabulary: A While vs Awhile
220.description:
Its been a while since I last saw you. Go study awhile.
A while is a noun that stands for a period of time. Awhile is an adverb that also means ""a period of time""
To make the distinction a little clearer, notice how in the first sentence a while could be replaced with another unit of time, such as two months, and the sentence would still make sense.
Its been a while since I last saw you. Its been two months since I last saw you.
In the second sentence sentence, awhile could be replaced with another adjective, such as quietly, and still make sense.
Go study awhile. Go study quietly.

252.title: Verbs Beginning with ""to""
252.description: Correct: Mike learned how to read, write, and speak French. Correct: Mike learned how to read, to write, and to speak French. Incorrect: Mike learned how to read, write, and speaking French. If a list of actions begins with words like ""to read"", we do not write ""ing"" at the end of any action in the list.

208.description:
Your: I need to borrow your umbrella. You're: I hope that you're going to lend me one.
We use your when something belongs to ""you."" You're means ""you are.""
208.title: Your, You're

40.description:
Correct: My grandparents keep a picture of me on their mantle. Incorrect: My grandparents keep a picture of me at their mantle.
We use on for anything on a surface, like walls and tables.
40.title: On (Place)

359.title: Practice: Themselves, Ourselves, Itself, Herself.
359.description:
Reflexive: Steven sees himself becoming team captain one day. Non-Reflexive: I see Steven becoming team captain one day.
If a male subject (Steven) does something to himself, we use a reflexive pronoun (himself). In the second example, the subject (I) is seeing someone else, so we do not use a reflexive pronoun.

450.description:
Separate: I have not contacted Mrs. Robinson. Contraction: I haven't contacted Mrs. Robinson.
To make ""have"" and ""not"" a contraction, we write haven't.
450.title: Practice: Haven't, Don't

364.description:
Correct: I will meet my friend at noon. Incorrect: I will meet my friend on noon.
We use the preposition at for specific times, like 1:30 PM or 7:00 AM.
364.title: Practice: At, In, On (Time)

180.title: Eaten
180.description: Correct: I have eaten pancakes before. Incorrect: I have eated pancakes before. The past participle for ""eat"" is eaten.

4.title: Possessive Nouns
4.description: Example: My father's stamp collection is huge. [My father owns the stamp collection] Example: The ship's sails were filled with a gust of wind. [The sails belong to the ship] Possessive nouns are used to show ownership. To make most common or proper nouns possessive, we add an apostrophe and an ""s"" to the end of the word. Whatever comes after the possessive noun belongs to it. For example, my father's stamp collection and the ship's sail are possessive nouns.

228.title: Plural vs. Singular Possessive
228.description: Correct: The saddles on each horse were both comfortable and stylish. Incorrect: The saddle's on each horse were both comfortable and stylish. Plural words that do not own something are written without an apostrophe. Words with an apostrophe placed before an ""s"" are singular possessive words.

265.description:
Of: a button of a coat, north of Chicago, member of a team. Off: turn off the lights, my shoes are off, break off some bread.
We use the word of to show how one thing is connected to another thing.
We use the word off to say that something is no longer connected to something else.
265.title: Of vs. Off

24.description:
Not Connected: I don't like hamburgers. I will have spaghetti. Connected: I don't like hamburgers, so I will have spaghetti.
So connects two related sentences into one larger one. In the example, so is used because the subject (I) does not like hamburgers, and has spaghetti instead.
24.title: So

365.title: In (Time)
365.description:
Correct: I will meet my cousin in the fall. Incorrect: I will meet my cousin at the fall.
We use in for months, seasons, and times of day, like October, winter or morning.

296.description:
That: The new classrooms that had their walls painted look great. Which: The new classrooms, which had their walls painted, look great.
We use which to give more details about something (new classrooms), but the details don't change the meaning of the sentence. In the first example, using ""that"" means only the painted classrooms look great. In the second example, using which means that the new classrooms look great, and they also happen to be painted. We usually place commas before which.
296.title: Which

448.description: Correct: Let's play a board game together. Incorrect: Lets play a board game together. Let's means ""let us"" and is used for suggestions. Lets without an apostrophe means ""to allow.""
448.title: Let's

506.description:
Correct: Which holiday is closest to today, Christmas, Hanukkah, Valentine's Day, or Easter? Incorrect: Which holiday is closest to today, christmas, hanukkah, valentines day, or easter?
When we write holiday names, we always capitalize the first letter of all the words (New Year's Eve, Christmas Day, Fourth of July).
506.title: Practice: Capitalize Holidays, Product Names, and Geographic Names

345.title: Hid
345.description:
Correct: Janice hid a note in my backpack. Incorrect: Janice hided a note in my backpack.
The past tense of ""hide"" is hid.

178.title: Addressing People
178.description: Correct: Can we go, Paul? Incorrect: Can we go Paul? Correct: Sarah, you should go to practice. Incorrect: Sarah you should go to practice. If we address somebody at the end of a sentence, we place a comma before their name. If we address somebody at the beginning of a sentence we place a comma after their name.

326.title: Practice: Comparative and Superlative Adjectives Ending in ""y""
326.description: Correct: Papayas are considered to be healthier than bananas. Incorrect: Papayas are considered to be healthyer than bananas. To make an adjective ending in ""y"" (healthy) comparative, we change the ""y"" to an ""ier"" to the end of the word (**healthier**).

360.description:
Reflexive: Jasmine heard herself singing through the speakers. Non-Reflexive: He heard Jasmine singing through the speakers.
If a female subject (Jasmine) does something to herself, we use a reflexive pronoun (herself). In the second example, the subject (He) is listening to someone else, so we do not use a reflexive pronoun.
360.title: Herself

106.title: Whose
106.description:
Correct: My friend Steve, whose job is fun, loves going to work. Incorrect: My friend Steve, who job is fun, loves going to work.
We use whose to give more details about something the subject (Steve) owns (job).

32.title: This & That
32.description:
Close by: This picture here is crooked. Further away: That picture over there is crooked.
You use this and that when you are talking a single thing (a picture). You use this for things near you and that for things further away.

189.title: The Passive Voice
189.description: Active: I ate the chocolate bar on the table. Passive: The chocolate bar on the table was eaten. Verbs in the passive voice are made the same way past participles are made (eaten). They follow helping verbs like “was” and “were.”

167.title: Either ... Or
167.description: Exactly Two Options: You can have either soup or salad. Two Options, Maybe More: You can have soup or salad. Whenever either is placed before or, we are presented with exactly two options (soup or salad). If the two options share a verb, either is written after the verb (have either). If the two options have different verbs, either is written before the first verb (either have).

192.title: Ellipsis
192.description: With Ellipsis: ""I forgot what I went shopping for..."" Without Ellipsis: ""I forgot what I went shopping for."" Ellipses are used in informal writing. Like commas, they are used to show a pause. However, the ellipsis is often used when someone is speaking, and can also be used to show that the person hasn't finished what he or she might have said.

171.title: Commas in a List
171.description: Correct: This box has books, magazines, and newspaper articles. Incorrect: This box has books magazines and newspaper articles. We place commas after each item in a list (books, magazines,). We finish a list by placing the word ""and"" before the last item.

310.description:
Correct: My father, whom I respect, is a self-made man. Incorrect: My father, who I respect, is a self-made man.
We use whom to give more details about someone (My father) who receives an action (I respect) instead of doing an action. The example above says that someone (I) respects her father, which means that ""father"" receives the action, ""respect"".
310.title: Whom

174.description: With Still: I don't like roller coasters. Still, I think theme parks are fun. Without Still: I don't like roller coasters. I think theme parks are fun. We use still at the beginning of a sentence to say something is true despite what was said earlier. We place a comma after still (Still, I think theme parks are fun).
174.title: Still

382.description:
Close by: These shoes are dirty. Further away: Those dogs are cute.
You use these and those when you are talking about more than one thing. You use these for things near you and those for things further away.
382.title: Practice: These & Those

331.description: Correct: My favorite book is called A Return to the Beginnings of Time and Space. Incorrect: My favorite book is called A return to the beginnings of time and space. When we write out titles, we always capitalize the first word in the title along with proper nouns and longer words. Smaller words like articles (the), conjunctions (but), and prepositions (to) remain in the lower case.
331.title: Capitalize Appropriate Words in Titles

183.description: Correct: We have made many mistakes before coming to the right conclusion. Incorrect: We have maked many mistakes before coming to the right conclusion. The past participle for ""make"" is made.
183.title: Made

87.description:
Adjective: Careful, that knife is sharp. Adverb: I sharply turned the car around.
If an adjective ends in a consonant (sharp), then we usually add ""ly"" onto the end of the adjective to make it an adverb (sharply).
87.title: Adjectives to Adverbs: Consonant Ending

338.description:
Correct: I did too much work today. Incorrect: I doed too much work today.
The past tense of ""do"" is did.
338.title: Did

281.description:
To: I sent an email to you. Too: Brett sent you an email too. Two: Pat sent you not one, but two emails.
To is used mostly to show where something is moving Too can either mean ""also"" or ""excessive"". Two is the number after ""one"".
281.title: To, Too, & Two

203.description:
Greece is the name of a country. The people who live in Greece are called Greeks, and they speak the Greek language. Since Greece is the name of a country, it is always capitalized.
Grease (noun) is an oily or fatty substance. To grease (verb) means to smear something with grease. If something is covered with grease, it is greasy (adjective). The phrase ""greasy spoon"" refers to a restaurant where there is a lot of fried food on the menu.
203.title: Greece, Grease

82.title: Wrote
82.description:
Correct: My brother wrote me an email, but I never received it. Incorrect: My brother writed me an email, but I never received it.
The past tense of ""write"" is wrote.

217.title: Vocabulary: Breath vs Breathe
217.description:
""Don't forget to breathe during the sprints, it will make you run faster."" It was so cold in my room last night I could see my breath.
breath is the verb ""to breath"" as in to inhale. breathe is the air that you exhale, your breathe.

158.title: Superlative Adjectives
158.description: Correct: James is the tallest guy in school. Incorrect: James is the most tall guy in school. Superlative adjectives tell us how one thing (James) is the ""most"" or ""least"". Regular superlative adjectives are formed by adding ""est"" to the end of a word (**tallest**).

381.title: These & Those
381.description:
Close by: These shoes are dirty. Further away: Those dogs are cute.
You use these and those when you are talking about more than one thing. You use these for things near you and those for things further away.

124.description:
Prepositional Adverb: The man reached under the desk.
An adverbial prepositional phrase describes how something is being done.
Adverb prepositional phrases (under the desk) are placed after a verb (reached).
124.title: Prepositional Phrases: Adverb

235.description: Correct: In his excitement, the athlete shouted, ""I won!"" Incorrect: In his excitement, the athlete shouted, ""i won!"" The first letter of the first word in a quotation is always capitalized.
235.title: Capitalize the First Word of a Quotation.

129.title: Than vs. Then
129.description:
Than: I am older than my brother. Then: The sky was pink, and then it became dark.
We use than to compare two or more things. We use then to say ""at that time.""

74.description:
Correct: I did too much work today. Incorrect: I doed too much work today.
The past tense of ""do"" is did.
74.title: Did

211.title: It's, Its
211.description:
It's: It's a nice day. Its: The dog wags its tail.
It's is the same as ""it is"".
Its means the object (tail) belongs to the subject (dog).

6.description: Incorrect: My birthday is on wednesday, may 4th, 1994. Correct: My birthday is on Wednesday, May 4th, 1994. We capitalize the names of specific days and months (Wednesday, May).
6.title: Capitalize Dates

133.title: First Word of a Sentence
133.description:
Correct: You should climb Mount Washington. Incorrect: you should climb Mount Washington.
Whenever we begin a new sentence, we always capitalize the first letter of the first word (You) of the sentence.

454.description: Correct: My favorite team has lost only once this season. Incorrect: My favorite team has losed only once this season. The past participle for ""lose"" is lost.
454.title: Lost

156.title: Comparative Adjectives
156.description: Correct: James is taller than Steve. Incorrect: Jame is more tall than Steve. Comparative adjectives tell us how one thing (James) is ""more"" or ""less"" than another thing (Steve). Regular comparative adjectives are formed by adding ""er"" to the end of a word (**taller**).

354.description:
Reflexive: I hit myself with a ball playing soccer yesterday. Non-Reflexive: I was hit with a ball while playing soccer yesterday.
If a subject (I) does something to itself, we use a reflexive pronoun (myself). In the second example, the subject (I) does not do something to itself, so we do not use a reflexive pronoun.
354.title: Myself

27.description:
Incorrect: I climbed an tree. Correct: I climbed a tree.
Articles (a) are used before nouns (tree). The article an is used before nouns that start with vowel sounds (a, e, i, o, u).
27.title: A

72.title: Built
72.description:
Correct: My mom built that chicken coop last year. Incorrect: My mom builded that chicken coop last year.
The past tense of ""build"" is built.

110.description:
Incorrect: Did you get the email who I sent this morning? Correct: Did you get the email that I sent this morning?
We use that to give more details about an object (the email). Unlike ""which"", we use that when the details are are important to the meaning of the sentence (that I sent this morning). We usually don't place commas before that.
110.title: That

165.title: Singular Possessive
165.description:
Correct: I think that is Jane's notebook. Incorrect: That is Janes notebook.
Possessive nouns are used to show ownership of the noun written after it (Jane's notebook). Singular possessive nouns are usually made by adding an apostrophe and an ""s"" to the end of the word.

150.description:
Correct: My sister, who just received her law degree, is moving to New York. Incorrect: My sister who just received her law degree is moving to New York.
We put commas before and after nonrestrictive clauses (,who just received her law degree,). Nonrestrictive clauses provide additional information about a subject. We use these commas to show that this information is less important.
150.title: Commas Around Clauses

357.title: Yourselves
357.description:
Reflexive: I see that you all really applied yourselves for this assignment. Non-Reflexive: I see that you worked really hard for this assignment.
When we address multiple people (you all) doing something to themselves, we use a reflexive pronoun (yourselves).

42.title: Capitalization: Dates
42.description:
Correct: My birthday is on Wednesday, May 4th, 1994. Incorrect: My birthday is on wednesday, may 4th, 1994.
We capitalize the names of specific days and months (Wednesday, May).

168.description: Not only … but also: He was not only an excellent athlete, but also a great musician. And: He was an excellent athlete and a great musician. We use not only and but also to connect two different ideas to something. We always place a comma before but also in these kinds of sentences. Not only is usually placed before one idea, while but also is used instead of the word ""and.""
168.title: Not Only ... But Also

142.description:
Intensive: I organized the meeting myself. Reflexive: I organized myself before going to the meeting.
Intensive Pronouns (myself) use the same words as reflexive pronouns (myself). However, when using intensive pronouns, the subject (I) emphasizes that it does something (organized the meeting). It did not do something to itself (organized myself).
142.title: Intensive Pronouns vs. Reflexive Pronouns

12.title: Possessive Nouns
12.description: Example: My father's stamp collection is huge. Example: The ship's sails were filled with a gust of wind. Possessive nouns are used to show ownership. To make most common or proper nouns possessive, we add an apostrophe and an ""s"" to the end of the word.

416.title: Use Collective Nouns-2
416.description:
Correct: Thepanel of jurors found him innocent. Incorrect: Thebunch of jurors found him innocent.
Panel is a collective noun generally used to describe a group of figures with authority that are discussing something. For example, judges, juries, advisors, aids, etc...

289.description:
Correct: My friend Steve, whose job is fun, loves going to work. Incorrect: My friend Steve, who job is fun, loves going to work.
We use whose to give more details about something the subject (Steve) owns (job).
289.title: Whose

101.description:
Separate: That is a good idea. Contraction: That's a good idea.
To make a contraction with ""that"" and ""is"", we write that's.
101.title: That's

460.description: Correct: I have eaten pancakes before. Incorrect: I have eated pancakes before. The past participle for ""eat"" is eaten.
460.title: Eaten

1.description:
Of: a bunch of bananas, member of a team, son of a friend, north of Chicago. Off: turn off the lights, my shoes are off, break off some bread.
We use the word of to show how one thing is connected to another thing. We use off to say that something is no longer connected to something else.
1.title: Off vs. Of

442.title: Practice: I've, That's, It's
442.description:
Separate: I have been to Mexico before. Contraction: I've been to Mexico before.
To make a contraction with ""I"" and ""have"", we write I've.

419.description:
Past: I walked to school. Present: I walk to school.
When we want to talk about things that happened earlier, we usually add ""ed"" to the end of regular verbs to make them past tense.
419.title: Past Tense

387.title: Practice: Change Sentences from Active to Passive

25.title: Because
25.description:
Not Connected: I like this spaghetti. There is a lot of cheese in it. Connected: I like this spaghetti because there is a lot of cheese in it.
Because connects two sentences into one longer sentence. In the example, because is used to show that the amount of cheese is the reason the spaghetti is liked.

463.description: With However: My friend said the ride was safe. However, I didn't believe him. Without However: My friend said the ride was safe. I did not believe him. We use however at the beginning of a sentence to say ""nevertheless"" or ""but"". We place a comma after however (However, I did not believe him).
463.title: Practice: However, Still

511.title: Writing Lists
511.description:
Incorrect: I'll have milk and toast and a muffin. Correct: I'll have milk, toast, and a muffin.
When we write lists of three or more, we put a comma after each item in the list. We also put the word ""and"" before the last item of the list.

443.description:
Separate: That is a good idea. Contraction: That's a good idea.
To make a contraction with ""that"" and ""is"", we write that's.
443.title: That's

474.title: Using Periods with Numbers
474.description:
Correct: They hiked 1.7 miles. Incorrect: They hiked 1. 7 miles.
We do not put a space before or after a period when we are writing numbers.

333.description:
Correct: He broke my favorite cup. Incorrect: He breaked my favorite cup.
The past tense of """"break"""" is broke.
333.title: Broke

351.description:
Correct: We saw a wild boar the other day in the woods. Incorrect: We seen a wild boar the other day in the woods.
The past tense of ""see"" is saw.
351.title: Practice: Saw, Dug, Found

56.title: Child vs. Children
56.description:
Correct: Where are the children playing right now? Incorrect: Where are the childs playing right now?
The word ""child"" has an irregular plural form. To make it plural, we add ""ren"" to the end (children).

238.description: Correct: ""There is something stuck in your teeth,"" said the little boy. Incorrect: ""There is something stuck in your teeth."" said the little boy. When we write a quotation before a speaking verb, we place a comma at the end of the quotation just before the quotation mark. This comma replaces periods.
238.title: Commas At the End of Quotations

15.description:
Subject is I: I run a half-mile everyday. Subject is She: She runs a half-mile everyday.
Subjects (I, she) and verbs (run, runs) have to agree with each other. If the subject of a sentence is ""I"", ""you"" or ""they"", we don't change the verb. If the subject is ""he"", ""she"", or ""it"", we add an ""s"" to the end of the verb.
15.title: Singular And Plural Nouns

459.title: Practice: Eaten, Been, Regular Past Participles
459.description: With a Helping Verb: I have walked to the library before. As an Adjective: Gene had chilled fruit with his lunch. Regular past participles are made by adding ""ed"" to the end of the verbs. We use the past participle with helping verbs like ""have"" or ""had"" (I have walked). Past participles can also be used as adjectives when they come before nouns (chilled fruit), or when they follow the verb ""be"".

90.title: Adjectives to Adverbs: Ending in ""e""
90.description:
Adjective: You are brave enough to face your fears. Adverb: Rita bravely faced her fears.
Adjectives ending in ""e"" (brave), become adverbs by simply adding ""ly"" to the end of the word (bravely).

196.title: Verbs Ending in ""ing""
196.description: Correct: Marcus enjoys hiking, climbing, and canoeing. Incorrect: Marcus enjoys hiking, to climb, and canoes all the time. When writing a list of actions, the flow and rhythm of the sentence is improved if all the items in the list (hiking, climbing, and canoeing) are formed the same way. If one action in a list ends with ""ing,"" the others should as well.

390.title: Ends with ""fe""
390.description:
Correct: Some people say cats have nine lives. Incorrect: Some people say cats have nine lifes.
Nouns that end in ""fe"" (life) have an irregular plural form. To make them plural, we change the ""fe"" (life) to ""ves"" (lives).

292.description:
Correct: My favorite time of year is autumn, when all the leaves change color. Incorrect: My favorite time of year is autumn, where all the leaves change color.
When is used to to talk about something happening (leaves change color) in on, or at a certain time (autumn).
292.title: When

369.description:
Correct: I had a great time in London. Incorrect: I had a great time at London.
We use in when we are inside or within a place, like in France, or in a car.
369.title: In (Place)

207.description:
Than: I am older than my brother. Then: The sky was pink, and then it became dark.
We use than to compare two or more things. We use then to say ""at that time.""
207.title: Then, Than

258.title: Neither ... Nor
258.description: Neither, nor: My friend is neither snowboarding nor skiing today. Either, or: My friend is either snowboarding or skiing today. Neither and nor are used the same way as the words ""either"" and ""or"". However, neither and nor are used for negative sentences.

423.title: And
423.description:
Not Connected: I like spaghetti. I like hamburgers. Connected: I like spaghetti and I like hamburgers.
And connects two sentences into one longer sentence. In the example, we use and to show that the subject ( I ) likes both spaghetti and hamburgers.

10.description:
Examples: man, woman, city, country, baseball team.
Common nouns are ordinary words for people, places, and things, such as man, or country. Common nouns are not capitalized.
10.title: Common Nouns

332.description: Correct: My favorite book is called A Return to the Beginnings of Time and Space. Incorrect: My favorite book is called A return to the beginnings of time and space. When we write out titles, we always capitalize the first word in the title along with proper nouns and longer words. Smaller words like articles (the), conjunctions (but), and prepositions (to) remain in the lower case.
332.title: Practice: Capitalize Appropriate Words in Titles

312.description:
That: The new classrooms that had their walls painted look great. Which: The new classrooms, which had their walls painted, look great.
We use which to give more details about something (new classrooms), but the details don't change the meaning of the sentence. In the first example, using ""that"" means only the painted classrooms look great. In the second example, using which means that the new classrooms look great, and they also happen to be painted. We usually place commas before which.
312.title: Practice: Which, That

291.title: That
291.description:
""Incorrect: Did you get the email who I sent this morning? Correct: Did you get the email that I sent this morning?
We use that to give more details about an object (the email). Unlike """"which"""", we use that when the details are are important to the meaning of the sentence (that I sent this morning). We usually don't place commas before that.
""

411.description:
Examples: John, Sarah, London, Japan, and Yankees
Proper nouns are names for people, places, and things, such as John, or Japan. All proper nouns are capitalized.
411.title: Proper Nouns

19.title: Future Tense
19.description:
Future: I will walk to school. Present: I walk to school.
We use the future tense to describe things that we think will happen. To make the future tense ( will walk ), we add the helping verb ""will"" before the verb ( walk ).

480.description: Correct: The drawing on the refrigerator was done by my son. Incorrect: The drawing was done by my son on the refrigerator. It is best to describe everything about something (drawing on the refrigerator) before mentioning other people or things related to it (done by my son). The first example mentions a drawing that is on the refrigerator, while the second example shows an odd situation where the son was on top of the refrigerator.
480.title: Practice: Misplaced Modifiers

145.title: Pronoun Shift: Plural
145.description:
Correct: If they stay in touch, most people will have a lot of options available to them. Incorrect: If you stay in touch, most people will have a lot of options available to them.
Pronouns need to stay the same in gender (she, he) and number (they, them). This means that if the subject is plural (they), then any pronouns referring to it will usually be plural as well (them).

496.title: Proper Nouns
496.description:
Correct: Do you have a class with Mr. Thompson? Incorrect: Do you have a class with mr. thompson?
We always capitalize the first letter of proper nouns (Mr. Thompson), which are people, places, and things, with names. We also capitalize any titles that might come before the proper noun, such as Mr., Ms., Dr., President, Professor, ect. Don't forget, ""I"" is a proper noun and is always capitalized.

181.title: Been
181.description: Correct: I have been in a band before. Incorrect: I have beed in a band before. The past participle for ""be"" is been.

215.description: I work on my flip turns every day at swim practice. Pop quizzes are an everyday occurrence in this class. Every day when written with a space, means literally every day. When written without a space, everyday becomes an adjective that means common place or frequently occurring.
215.title: Vocabulary: Every Day vs Everyday

117.title: Future Progressive
117.description:
Simple Future: Alice will watch TV when her mother comes home. Future Progressive: Alice will be watching TV when her mother comes home.
Future progressive tense describes an ongoing action (watching tv) that will take place in the future (when her mother comes home). This tense is made by putting words like “will be” or “shall be” in front of the verb, and adding “ing” to the end of the verb (will be watching).

401.description:
Correct: Where are the children playing right now? Incorrect: Where are the childs playing right now?
The word ""child"" has an irregular plural form. To make it plural, we add ""ren"" to the end (children).
401.title: Practice: Children, People

317.description:
Correct: Please tell me why you missed the meeting. Incorrect: Please tell me where you missed the meeting.
Why is used to talk about something happening (missed the meeting) for a certain reason.
317.title: Why

239.title: Commas after Introductory Prepositional Phrases
239.description: Correct: In 1492, Columbus crossed the ocean blue. IncorrectIn 1492 Columbus crossed the ocean blue. When a sentence begins with a prepositional phrase (on the docks, at the park, in 1522), we always put a comma the introductory prepositional phrase.

303.title: Whom
303.description:
Correct: My father, whom I respect, is a self-made man. Incorrect: My father, who I respect, is a self-made man.
We use whom to give more details about someone (My father) who receives an action (I respect) instead of doing an action. The example above says that someone (I) respects her father, which means that ""father"" receives the action, ""respect"".

230.title: Let's
230.description: Correct: Let's play a board game together. Incorrect: Lets play a board game together. Let's means ""let us"" and is used for suggestions. Lets without an apostrophe means ""to allow.""

224.title: Vocabulary: Shown vs Shone
224.description:
I was shown around the mansion by the butler. Pure white light shone down brilliantly around us.
Shown is the past participle of the verb ""to show"". Shone the past participle of the verb ""to shine"".

408.title: Practice: Singular And Plural Nouns
408.description:
Subject is I: I run a half-mile everyday. Subject is She: She runs a half-mile everyday.
Subjects (I, she) and verbs (run, runs) have to agree with each other. If the subject of a sentence is ""I"", ""you"" or ""they"", we don't change the verb. If the subject is ""he"", ""she"", or ""it"", we add an ""s"" to the end of the verb.

352.description:
Incorrect: The fox quickly digged a hole in the snow to keep warm. Correct: The fox quickly dug a hole in the snow to keep warm.
The past tense of ""dig"" is dug.
352.title: Dug

261.title: Both ... And
261.description: With Both: Both Tom and Michelle like swimming. Without Both: Tom likes swimming. Michelle also likes swimming. Both can be used with and to describe two things at the same time (Both Tom and Michelle). We place both before the first thing, then use and for the second thing.

467.description: Correct: In 1492, Columbus crossed the ocean blue. IncorrectIn 1492 Columbus crossed the ocean blue. When a sentence begins with a prepositional phrase (on the docks, at the park, in 1522), we always put a comma the introductory prepositional phrase.
467.title: Commas after Introductory Prepositional Phrases

486.title: Possessive Pronouns
486.description:
Correct: Our project is more difficult than theirs. Incorrect: Our project is more difficult than they. Also Incorrect: Our project is more difficult than them.
Possessive pronouns (theirs) are words like ""mine"", ""yours"", ""his"", ""hers"", ""its"", ""ours"", and ""theirs"". They refer to something the subject owns (project).

330.title: Worse & Worst
330.description: Correct: It is worse to have never tried than to fail. Incorrect: It is badder to have never tried than to fail. The comparative adjective for ""bad"" is worse. The superlative adjective for ""bad"" is worst.

65.title: Herself
65.description:
Reflexive: Jasmine heard herself singing through the speakers. Non-Reflexive: He heard Jasmine singing through the speakers.
If a female subject (Jasmine) does something to herself, we use a reflexive pronoun (herself). In the second example, the subject (He) is listening to someone else, so we do not use a reflexive pronoun.

104.title: You're
104.description:
Separate: You are responsible for logging your work. Contraction: You're responsible for logging your work.
We use you're to say that you are doing something.

263.description:
It's: It's time to go. Its: The dog wags its tail.
It's is the same as ""it is"".
Its is possessive, meaning the object (tail) belongs to the subject (dog).
263.title: Its vs. It's

201.title: Finally, Finely
201.description:
The adverb finally means in the end, at last. Compare the adjective: final.
The adverb finely can mean ""in tiny pieces"" or it can mean ""elegantly, nicely."" Compare the adjective: fine.

148.description:
Vague: Mary orchestrated tonight's show, while Tia was in charge of all the design work. She works really hard. Specific: Mary orchestrated tonight's show, while Tia was in charge of all the design work. Tia works really hard.
In the first example, it is not clear whether she refers to Mary or to Tia.
In the second sentence Tia replaces she, making it clear who works really hard.
148.title: Vague Pronouns: More Than One Subject

213.title: Verbs Beginning with ""to""
213.description: Correct: Mike learned how to read, write, and speak French. Correct: Mike learned how to read, to write, and to speak French. Incorrect: Mike learned how to read, write, and speaking French. If a list of actions begins with words like ""to read"", we do not write ""ing"" at the end of any action in the list.

111.title: Where
111.description:
Correct: Let's go to the living room, where we will serve drinks. Incorrect: Let's go to the living room, when we will serve drinks.
Where is used to talk about something happening (serve drinks) in, on, or at a certain place (living room).

85.description:
Adjective: The park we visited was really beautiful. Adverb: You performed beautifully yesterday.
Adjectives (beautiful) are used to describe nouns (park).
85.title: Adjectives

98.title: Don't
98.description:
Separate: I do not go to school on Saturday. Contraction: I don't go to school on Saturday.
To make ""do"" and ""not"" a contraction, we write don't.

29.title: Practice: A vs. An
29.description:
Incorrect: I saw a owl last night. Correct: I saw an owl last night.
A is used before nouns that start with a consonant sound (everything but a, e, i, o, u). An is used before nouns that start with a vowel sound.

485.title: Object Pronouns
485.description:
Correct: Will you please call her when you finish the poster? Incorrect: Will you please call she when you finish the poster? Also Incorrect: Will you please call hers when you finish the poster?
Object pronouns (her) are words like ""me"", ""you"", ""him"", ""her"", ""it"", ""us"", and ""them"". Object pronouns go after the verb (call).

373.title: An
373.description:
Incorrect: I climbed an tree. Correct: I climbed a tree.
Articles (a) are used before nouns (tree). The article an is used before nouns that start with vowel sounds (a, e, i, o, u).

262.description:
It's: It's time to go. Its: The dog wags its tail.
It's is the same as ""it is"".
Its is possessive, meaning the object (tail) belongs to the subject (dog).
262.title: Its vs. It's

385.description:
Active Voice: The student use Quill.
Passive Voice: Quill is used by the students.
A verb's voice tells whether a subject receives or performs an action. If the subject receives the action, it is passive, and if the subject performs the action, it is active.
The passive voice is usually written with a form of ""to be"" and then the past participle of a verb.
385.title: Change into Proper Passive or Active Sentences-2

131.description:
Your: I need to borrow your umbrella. You're: I hope that you're going to lend me one.
We use your when something belongs to ""you."" You're means ""you are.""
131.title: Your vs. You're

414.title: Use Collective Nouns-1
414.description:
Correct: The red team scored the winning goal in the game. Incorrect: The red panel scored the winning goal in the game.
Collective nouns are words like team, panel, bunch, pack, etc. They usually are singular and describe a group of things (group of people).
Team is a collective noun generally used to describe a group working towards a common cause, or in competition with another group. For example, a sports team, oxen team, or

108.title: Which
108.description:
That: The new classrooms that had their walls painted look great. Which: The new classrooms, which had their walls painted, look great.
We use which to give more details about something (new classrooms), but the details don't change the meaning of the sentence. In the first example, using ""that"" means only the painted classrooms look great. In the second example, using which means that the new classrooms look great, and they also happen to be painted. We usually place commas before which.

122.title: Prepositional Phrases: Noun
122.description:
Is: John is behind the curtain. Are: The men are next to the bar. Am: I am under a bridge.
A nominal prepositional phrase is used to say where something is. Nominal prepositional phrases (behind the curtain, next to the bar, under a bridge) are placed after the verb to be (is, are, am).

313.description:
Incorrect: Did you get the email who I sent this morning? Correct: Did you get the email that I sent this morning?
We use that to give more details about an object (the email). Unlike ""which"", we use that when the details are are important to the meaning of the sentence (that I sent this morning). We usually don't place commas before that.
313.title: That

465.title: Meanwhile
465.description: With Meanwhile: I was cleaning the whole house. Meanwhile, my brother was still sleeping. Without Meanwhile: I was cleaning the whole house. My brother was still sleeping. We use meanwhile at the beginning of a sentence to say two events are happening at the same time. We place a comma after meanwhile (Meanwhile, my brother was still sleeping).

204.title: Clean, Cleanse
204.description:
The word clean can be a verb (I clean, you clean, she cleans), and it can also be an adjective (my clothes are clean). You can make the word into a noun by adding -er: a ""cleaner"" is someone or something who cleans.
The word cleanse is a verb that means to make something completely clean. It can also mean to wash away a stain or impurity. The word is pronounced: /klens/ (rhymes with the word ""lens""). You can also turn this verb into a noun by adding -(e)r: a ""cleanser"" is someone or something that cleanses.

436.title: Practice: Ajectives to Adverbs in ""le"" and ""e""

46.title: Writing Lists
46.description:
Incorrect: I'll have milk and toast and a muffin. Correct: I'll have milk, toast, and a muffin.
When we write lists of three or more, we put a comma after each item in the list. We also put the word ""and"" before the last item of the list.

226.description:
Correct: We saw a wild boar the other day in the woods. Incorrect: We seen a wild boar the other day in the woods.
The past tense of ""see"" is saw.
226.title: Saw

67.description:
Reflexive: We worked ourselves to the point of exhaustion. Non-Reflexive: Our company works almost 80 hours a week.
If the subject (We) does something to itself, we use a reflexive pronoun (ourselves). In the second example, the company is making us work instead of us working ourselves, so we do not use a reflexive pronoun.
67.title: Ourselves

92.description:
Correct: Which holiday is closest to today, Christmas, Hanukkah, Valentine's Day, or Easter? Incorrect: Which holiday is closest to today, christmas, hanukkah, valentines day, or easter?
When we write holiday names, we always capitalize the first letter of all the words (New Year's Eve, Christmas Day, Fourth of July).
92.title: Holidays

152.title: Using Periods
152.description:
Correct: I went to the zoo. I saw an elephant. Incorrect: I went to the zoo.I saw an elephant. Incorrect: I went to the zoo .I saw an elephant.
We put a space after a period.

323.description: Correct: James is taller than Steve. Incorrect: Jame is more tall than Steve. Comparative adjectives tell us how one thing (James) is ""more"" or ""less"" than another thing (Steve). Regular comparative adjectives are formed by adding ""er"" to the end of a word (**taller**).
323.title: Practice: Comparative and Superlative Adjectives

269.description:
Lose: lose my keys, lose a game, lose one's balance. Loose: the screws were loose, it broke loose.
We use lose when we can't find something, don't have something, or didn't win.
We use loose when something isn't tight, or something is freed.
We use the word of to show how one thing is connected to another thing.
We use the word off to say that something is no longer connected to something else.
269.title: Lose vs. Loose

233.description: Correct: The sign by the school tells us that we need to drive slowly. Incorrect: The sign by the school tells us that ""we need to drive slowly."" Quotation marks go around direct speech. This means that we place quotation marks around what somebody says, or what a text says. We do not quote what something has told us or tells us (tells us that we need to drive slowly).
233.title: Direct vs. Indirect Speech

3.description: There: There is a park by the lake. They're: They're going to the park. Their: They left their Frisbee at the park. There is used for locations. They're is the same as ""they are"". Their is used when something (they) owns something else (frisbee).
3.title: There, They're, Their

489.description: Correct: Yes, my husband is a lawyer. Incorrect: Yes my husband is a lawyer. Correct: No, I don't want to go. Incorrect: No I don't want to go. When we begin a sentence with yes or no, we always put a comma afterwards.
489.title: Yes & No

487.description: Positive: We are going to make it, aren't we? Negative: You aren't on my team, are you? Tag questions are little questions that we place at the end of sentences when we want to confirm what we just asked, or suggest an answer. If the first part of the sentence is positive (we are going to make it) then the tag question is negative (aren't we). If the first part is negative, then the tag question is positive.
487.title: Tag Questions

136.description:
Correct: I live on 15 Deepwood Rd in Hartford CT. Incorrect: I live on 15 deepwood rd in hartford ct.
The names of roads, towns, and states in addresses are all proper nouns, so they are capitalized. Don't forget to capitalize all the proper nouns in your address whenever you write it down.
136.title: Addresses

477.description: Correct: That hat doesn't fit me because it is too small. Incorrect: That hat didn't fit me because it is too small. Everything that happens in the present must be written in the present tense (doesn't fit me because it is too small). For things that happen in the past, everything must be written in the past tense. Lastly, everything that happens in the future must be written in the future tense.
477.title: Verb Tense Shift

466.title: Practice: Commas after Introductory Prepositional Phrases
466.description: With Meanwhile: I was cleaning the whole house. Meanwhile, my brother was still sleeping. Without Meanwhile: I was cleaning the whole house. My brother was still sleeping. We use meanwhile at the beginning of a sentence to say two events are happening at the same time. We place a comma after meanwhile (Meanwhile, my brother was still sleeping).

507.description:
Correct: My favorite baseball team is the Yankees. Incorrect: My favorite baseball team is the yankees.
We capitalize all product names. Product names include companies (Microsoft), sports teams (Yankees), and brand names (Coca-Cola).
507.title: Product Names

426.description:
Not Connected: I don't like hamburgers. I will have spaghetti. Connected: I don't like hamburgers, so I will have spaghetti.
So connects two related sentences into one larger one. In the example, so is used because the subject (I) does not like hamburgers, and has spaghetti instead.
426.title: So

475.description: Correct: Our librarian always reminds us, ""Speak softly in the library."" Incorrect: Our librarian always reminds us, "" Speak softly in the library."" Whenever we use quotation marks, they always go right next to a word or punctuation (""Speak softly in the library.""). We never put in extra spaces between quotation marks and the words next to them.
475.title: Using Quotation Marks

249.title: Verb Tense
249.description: Correct: I laughed, I cried, and I shouted during the performance. Incorrect: I laughed, I was crying, and I shout during the performance. Sentences flow easily when all the actions in a list have the same ending. This means that each and every action in a list stays in the past, present, or future tense.

187.description: With ""and"": I just had a big and tasty calzone. Without ""and"": I just had a big, tasty calzone. Whenever you have two adjectives (big and tasty) describing something (calzone), you do not have to use ""and"" like you normally do for lists. You can write a comma after the first adjective to describe something (big, tasty calzone).
187.title: Two Adjectives

59.title: Person vs. People
59.description:
Correct: I think we can fit at east three people in each room. Incorrect: I think we can fit at least three persons in each room.
The word ""person"" has an irregular plural form. To make it plural, we change the ""rson"" (person) to ""ople"" (people).

176.description: Positive: We are going to make it, aren't we? Negative: You aren't on my team, are you? Tag questions are little questions that we place at the end of sentences when we want to agree, disagree, or confirm what someone just said. If the first part of the sentence is positive (we are going to make it) then the tag question is negative (aren't we).
176.title: Tag Questions

407.title: Singular And Plural Nouns
407.description:
Subject is I: I run a half-mile everyday. Subject is She: She runs a half-mile everyday.
Subjects (I, she) and verbs (run, runs) have to agree with each other. If the subject of a sentence is ""I"", ""you"" or ""they"", we don't change the verb. If the subject is ""he"", ""she"", or ""it"", we add an ""s"" to the end of the verb.

276.description:
""There: There is a park by the lake. They're: They're going to the park. Their: They left their frisbee at the park.
There is used for locations.
They're is the same as """"they are"""".
Their is used when something (they) owns something else (frisbee).
""
276.title: There, They're, & Their

282.title: Your vs. You're
282.description:
""Your: I need to borrow your umbrella. You're: I hope that you're going to lend me one.
We use your when something belongs to ""you."" You're means ""you are.""

73.description:
Correct: I'm glad you came to my party. Incorrect: I'm glad you comed to my party.
The past tense of ""come"" is came.
73.title: Came

476.title: Verb Tense Shift
476.description: Correct: That hat doesn't fit me because it is too small. Incorrect: That had didn't fit me because it is too small. Everything that happens in the present must be written in the present tense (doesn't fit me because it is too small). For things that happen in the past, everything must be written in the past tense. Lastly, everything that happens in the future must be written in the future tense.

374.title: Practice: This & That
374.description:
Close by: This picture here is crooked. Further away: That picture over there is crooked.
You use this and that when you are talking a single thing (a picture). You use this for things near you and that for things further away.

413.description: Example: My father's stamp collection is huge. Example: The ship's sails were filled with a gust of wind. Possessive nouns are used to show ownership. To make most common or proper nouns possessive, we add an apostrophe and an ""s"" to the end of the word.
413.title: Practice: Possessive Nouns

397.description:
""Correct: Can you juggle the ball with both feet? Incorrect: Can you juggle the ball with both foots?
The word """"foot"""" has an irregular plural form. To make it plural, we change the double """"o"""" (foot) into a double """"e"""" (feet).
""
397.title: Foot vs. Feet

219.description:
""Don't go in the sauna, its for grownups,"" said the mother to her daughter. ""When you are more grown-up you will learn to like broccoli.
Grownup is a noun which means an adult person. Grown-up when written with a hyphen, is an adjective that means adult-like, or no longer childish.
219.title: Vocabulary: Grownup vs Grown-up

336.description:
Correct: I'm glad you came to my party. Incorrect: I'm glad you comed to my party.
The past tense of ""come"" is came.
336.title: Came

23.title: Or
23.description:
Not Connected: Would you like spaghetti? Would you like a hamburger? Connected: Would you like spaghetti, or would you like a hamburger?
Or connects two sentences into one longer sentence. In the example, or is used to show a choice between spaghetti or a hamburger.

232.title: Let's vs Lets
232.description:
Let's go do some squats at the gym. My brother lets me use his computer sometimes.
Let's, when spelled with an apostrophe, is the contraction form of ""let us"". Lets, when spelled without an apostrophe, means ""allows"" or ""permits"".

335.description:
Correct: My mom built that chicken coop last year. Incorrect: My mom builded that chicken coop last year.
The past tense of """"build"""" is built.
335.title: Built

94.description:
Correct: I am moving to Los Angeles next month. Incorrect: I am moving to los angeles next month.
We capitalize the names of all geographic places (cities, countries, towns, mountains, etc).
94.title: Geographic Names

356.description:
Reflexive: Why don't you lift yourself out of the hole? Non-Reflexive: Why don't you lift Alex out of the hole?
If a subject (you) does something to its itself, we use a reflexive pronoun (yourself). Sentences where the subject (you) does not do something to itself (Alex) do not use a reflexive pronoun.
356.title: Yourself

362.description:
Reflexive: We worked ourselves to the point of exhaustion. Non-Reflexive: Our company works almost 80 hours a week.
If the subject (We) does something to itself, we use a reflexive pronoun (ourselves). In the second example, the company is making us work instead of us working ourselves, so we do not use a reflexive pronoun.
362.title: Ourselves

433.description:
Adjective: Careful, that knife is sharp. Adverb: I sharply turned the car around.
If an adjective ends in a consonant (sharp), then we usually add ""ly"" onto the end of the adjective to make it an adverb (sharply).
433.title: Practice: Adjectives to Adverbs: Consonant Ending and ""y"" Ending

195.description: Correct: I laughed, I cried, and I shouted during the performance. Incorrect: I laughed, I was crying, and I shout during the performance. Sentences flow easily when all the actions in a list have the same ending. This means that each and every action in a list stays in the past, present, or future tense.
195.title: Verb Tense

383.description:
Active Voice: The student use Quill.
Passive Voice: Quill is used by the students.
A verb's voice tells whether a subject receives or performs an action. If the subject receives the action, it is passive, and if the subject performs the action, it is active.
The passive voice is usually written with a form of ""to be"" and then the past participle of a verb.
383.title: Change into Proper Passive or Active Sentences-1

188.description: Correct: Our librarian always reminds us, ""Speak softly in the library."" Incorrect: Our librarian always reminds us, "" Speak softly in the library."" Whenever we use quotation marks, they always go right next to a word or punctuation (""Speak softly in the library.""). We never put in extra spaces between quotation marks and the words next to them.
188.title: Using Quotation Marks

83.title: Found
83.description:
Correct: I finally found my phone in my backpack. Incorrect: I finally finded my phone in my backpack.
The past tense of ""find"" is found.

173.title: However
173.description: With However: My friend said the ride was safe. However, I didn't believe him. Without However: My friend said the ride was safe. I did not believe him. We use however at the beginning of a sentence to say ""nevertheless"" or ""but."" We place a comma after however (However, I did not believe him).

81.description:
Correct: Everyone sat quietly while they waited to board the plane. Incorrect: Everyone sitted quietly while they waited to board the plane.
The past tense of ""sit"" is sat.
81.title: Sat

293.title: Whom
293.description:
""Correct: My father, whom I respect, is a self-made man. Incorrect: My father, who I respect, is a self-made man.
We use whom to give more details about someone (My father) who receives an action (I respect) instead of doing an action. The example above says that someone (I) respects her father, which means that """"father"""" receives the action, """"respect"""".
""
